<ul><li><img alt="" class="noviewer" data-file-height="215" data-file-width="206" decoding="async" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Allah-green.svg/15px-Allah-green.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Allah-green.svg/23px-Allah-green.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Allah-green.svg/31px-Allah-green.svg.png 2x" width="15"/>Â <a href="/wiki/Portal:Islam" title="Portal:Islam">Islam portal</a></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar" style="padding-right:0.2em;"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1063604349">.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:inline;font-size:88%;font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .navbar-collapse{float:left;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .navbar-boxtext{word-spacing:0}.mw-parser-output .navbar ul{display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::before{margin-right:-0.125em;content:"[ "}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::after{margin-left:-0.125em;content:" ]"}.mw-parser-output .navbar li{word-spacing:-0.125em}.mw-parser-output .navbar a>span,.mw-parser-output .navbar a>abbr{text-decoration:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-mini abbr{font-variant:small-caps;border-bottom:none;text-decoration:none;cursor:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-full{font-size:114%;margin:0 7em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-mini{font-size:114%;margin:0 4em}</style><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Islam" title="Template:Islam"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Islam" title="Template talk:Islam"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Islam&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p><p><b>Islam</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="/Éª/: 'i' in 'kit'">Éª</span><span title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</span><span title="'l' in 'lie'">l</span><span title="/ÉË/: 'a' in 'father'">ÉË</span><span title="'m' in 'my'">m</span></span>/</a></span></span>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6"><a href="#cite_note-6">[a]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø§ÙØ¥Ø³ÙØ§Ù</span>, <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">al-Ê¿IslÄm</i></span> <small></small><span class="IPA" lang="ar-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Arabic" title="Help:IPA/Arabic">[ÉªsËlaËm]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ar-islam.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f8/Ar-islam.ogg" title="Ar-islam.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>, <abbr title="translation">transl.</abbr><span>â"Submission [to <a href="/wiki/God_in_Islam" title="God in Islam">God</a>]"</span>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7"><a href="#cite_note-7">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8"><a href="#cite_note-8">[7]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9"><a href="#cite_note-9">[8]</a></sup> is an <a href="/wiki/Abrahamic_religions" title="Abrahamic religions">Abrahamic</a> <a href="/wiki/Monotheism#Islam" title="Monotheism">monotheistic religion</a> centred primarily around the <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a>, a religious text considered by <a href="/wiki/Muslims" title="Muslims">Muslims</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10">[9]</a></sup> to be the direct word of the <a href="/wiki/God_in_Abrahamic_religions" title="God in Abrahamic religions">God of Abraham</a> (or <i><a href="/wiki/Allah" title="Allah">Allah</a></i>) as it was revealed to <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_in_Islam" title="Muhammad in Islam">main and final Islamic prophet</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11"><a href="#cite_note-11">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OEIW-allah2_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-OEIW-allah2-12">[11]</a></sup> It is the <a href="/wiki/Major_religious_groups" title="Major religious groups">world's second-largest religion</a> behind <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>, with its followers ranging between 1-1.8 billion globally, or around 25 percent of the world population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pewresearch.org_5-1"><a href="#cite_note-pewresearch.org-5">[5]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[12]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pew2_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pew2-14">[13]</a></sup> Islam teaches that God is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mercy_in_Islam" title="Mercy in Islam">merciful</a>, <a href="/wiki/Omnipotence" title="Omnipotence">all-powerful</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tawhid" title="Tawhid">unique</a>,<sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampo200934"Allah"_15-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampo200934"Allah"-15'>[14]</a></sup> and has guided humanity through <a href="/wiki/Prophets_and_messengers_in_Islam" title="Prophets and messengers in Islam">various prophets</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islamic_holy_books" title="Islamic holy books">revealed scriptures</a>, and <a href="/wiki/%C4%80yah" title="Äyah">natural signs</a>, with the Quran serving as the final and universal revelation and Muhammad serving as the "<a href="/wiki/Seal_of_the_Prophets" title="Seal of the Prophets">Seal of the Prophets</a>" (the last prophet of God).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OEIW-allah2_12-1"><a href="#cite_note-OEIW-allah2-12">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[15]</a></sup> The teachings and practices of Muhammad (<span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Sunnah" title="Sunnah">sunnah</a></i></span>) documented in traditional collected accounts (<span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Hadith" title="Hadith">hadith</a></i></span>) provide a secondary constitutional model for Muslims to follow after the Quran.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[16]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 63">:â63â</span></sup>
</p><p>Muslims believe that Islam is the complete and universal version of a <a href="/wiki/Fitra" title="Fitra">primordial faith</a> that was revealed many times through earlier prophets such as <a href="/wiki/Adam_in_Islam" title="Adam in Islam">Adam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abraham_in_Islam" title="Abraham in Islam">Abraham</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moses_in_Islam" title="Moses in Islam">Moses</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jesus_in_Islam" title="Jesus in Islam">Jesus</a>, among others;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[17]</a></sup> these earlier revelations are attributed to <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>, which are regarded in Islam as <a href="/wiki/People_of_the_Book" title="People of the Book">spiritual predecessor faiths</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[18]</a></sup> They also consider the Quran, when preserved in <a href="/wiki/Classical_Arabic" title="Classical Arabic">Classical Arabic</a>, to be the unaltered and final revelation of God to humanity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBennett2010101_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBennett2010101-20">[19]</a></sup> Like other Abrahamic religions, Islam also teaches of a "<a href="/wiki/Last_Judgment" title="Last Judgment">Final Judgement</a>" wherein the righteous will be rewarded in <a href="/wiki/Paradise" title="Paradise">paradise</a> (<span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Jannah" title="Jannah">Jannah</a></i></span>) and the unrighteous will be punished in <a href="/wiki/Hell" title="Hell">hell</a> (<span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Jahannam" title="Jahannam">Jahannam</a></i></span>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[20]</a></sup> Religious concepts and practices include the <a href="/wiki/Five_Pillars_of_Islam" title="Five Pillars of Islam">Five Pillars of Islam</a>âconsidered obligatory acts of worshipâand following Islamic law (<span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">sharia</a></i></span>), which touches on virtually every aspect of life, from <a href="/wiki/Islamic_banking_and_finance" title="Islamic banking and finance">banking and finance</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zakat" title="Zakat">welfare</a> to <a href="/wiki/Women_in_Islam" title="Women in Islam">women's roles</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_ethics#Environmentalism" title="Islamic ethics">environment</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito2002b17,_111â112,_118_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito2002b17,_111â112,_118-22">[21]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:15_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-:15-23">[22]</a></sup> The cities of <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a>, <a href="/wiki/Medina" title="Medina">Medina</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a> are home to the <a href="/wiki/Holiest_sites_in_Islam" title="Holiest sites in Islam">three holiest sites in Islam</a>, in descending order: <a href="/wiki/Masjid_al-Haram" title="Masjid al-Haram">Masjid al-Haram</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al-Masjid_an-Nabawi" title="Al-Masjid an-Nabawi">Al-Masjid an-Nabawi</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Temple_Mount" title="Temple Mount">Al-Aqsa Mosque</a>, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[23]</a></sup>
</p><p>Islam originated in the 7th century at <a href="/wiki/Jabal_al-Nour" title="Jabal al-Nour">Jabal al-Nour</a>, a mountain peak near Mecca where <a href="/wiki/Muhammad%27s_first_revelation" title="Muhammad's first revelation">Muhammad's first revelation</a> is said to have taken place.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[24]</a></sup> Through various <a href="/wiki/Caliphate" title="Caliphate">caliphates</a>, the religion later <a href="/wiki/Spread_of_Islam" title="Spread of Islam">spread outside of Arabia</a> shortly after Muhammad's death, and by the 8th century, the <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad Caliphate</a> had imposed Islamic rule from the <a href="/wiki/Al-Andalus" title="Al-Andalus">Iberian Peninsula</a> in the west to the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_rulers_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="Islamic rulers in the Indian subcontinent">Indus Valley</a> in the east. The <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age" title="Islamic Golden Age">Islamic Golden Age</a> refers to the period traditionally dated from the 8th century to the 13th century, during the reign of the <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphate" title="Abbasid Caliphate">Abbasid Caliphate</a>, when much of the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_world" title="Muslim world">Muslim world</a> was experiencing a <a href="/wiki/Science_in_the_medieval_Islamic_world" title="Science in the medieval Islamic world">scientific</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Islamic_economics#Classical_Muslim_commerce" title="History of Islamic economics">economic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Islamic_culture" title="Islamic culture">cultural flourishing</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[26]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[27]</a></sup> The expansion of the Muslim world involved <a href="/wiki/List_of_Muslim_states_and_dynasties" title="List of Muslim states and dynasties">various states and caliphates</a> as well as extensive trade and religious conversion as a result of <a href="/wiki/Islamic_missionary_activity" title="Islamic missionary activity">Islamic missionary activities</a> (<span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Dawah" title="Dawah">dawah</a></i></span>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[28]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 125â258">:â125â258â</span></sup>
</p><p>There are two major <a href="/wiki/Islamic_schools_and_branches" title="Islamic schools and branches">Islamic denominations</a>: <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni Islam</a> (85â90 percent)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Denny_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-Denny-30">[29]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shia Islam</a> (10â15 percent);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_Factbook_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Factbook-31">[30]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-berkleycenter-sunni_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-berkleycenter-sunni-32">[31]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPew_Forum_for_Religion_&amp;_Public_Life20091_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPew_Forum_for_Religion_&amp;_Public_Life20091-33">[32]</a></sup> combined, they make up a majority of the population in <a href="/wiki/Islam_by_country" title="Islam by country">49 countries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[33]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[34]</a></sup> While <a href="/wiki/Shia%E2%80%93Sunni_relations" title="ShiaâSunni relations">SunniâShia differences</a> initially arose from disagreements over the <a href="/wiki/Succession_to_Muhammad" title="Succession to Muhammad">succession to Muhammad</a>, they grew to cover a broader dimension both <a href="/wiki/Schools_of_Islamic_theology" title="Schools of Islamic theology">theologically</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fiqh" title="Fiqh">juridically</a>, with the divergence acquiring notable political significance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EMMENA_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-EMMENA-36">[35]</a></sup> Approximately 12 percent of the world's Muslims live in <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Indonesia" title="Islam in Indonesia">Indonesia</a>, the most populous Muslim-majority country;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[36]</a></sup> 31 percent live in <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_South_Asia" title="Islam in South Asia">South Asia</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[37]</a></sup> 20 percent live in the <a href="/wiki/MENA#Religion" title="MENA">Middle EastâNorth Africa</a>; and 15 percent live in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Religion_in_Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Religion in Sub-Saharan Africa">sub-Saharan Africa</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-:3-39">[38]</a></sup> Sizable Muslim communities are also present in the <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_the_Americas" title="Islam in the Americas">Americas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_China" title="Islam in China">China</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Europe" title="Islam in Europe">Europe</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[39]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[40]</a></sup>
</p>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-9"><a href="#Acts_of_worship"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Acts of worship</span></a>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology<span class="anchor" id="Etymology"></span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Muslims#Etymology" title="Muslims">Muslims Â§Â Etymology</a></div>
<p>In Arabic, <i>Islam</i> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø¥Ø³ÙØ§Ù</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Literal_translation" title="Literal translation">lit.</a>â</small>'submission [to God]') is the verbal noun originating from the verb <span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø³ÙÙ</span></span> (<span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">salama</i></span>), from <a href="/wiki/Semitic_root" title="Semitic root">triliteral root</a> <span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø³-Ù-Ù</span></span> (<span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn"><a href="/wiki/%C5%A0-L-M" title="Å -L-M">S-L-M</a></i></span>), which forms a large class of words mostly relating to concepts of wholeness, submission, sincerity, safeness, and peace.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[41]</a></sup> <i>Islam</i> is the verbal noun of <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D8%A3%D8%B3%D9%84%D9%85#Arabic" title="wikt:Ø£Ø³ÙÙ">Form IV</a> of the root and means "submission" or "total surrender". In a religious context, it means "total surrender to the will of <a href="/wiki/God" title="God">God</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BC3_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-BC3-43">[42]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGardetJomier2012_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGardetJomier2012-44">[43]</a></sup> A <i><a href="/wiki/Muslims" title="Muslims">Muslim</a></i> (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">ÙÙØ³ÙÙÙÙ</span></span>), the word for a follower of Islam, is the <a href="/wiki/Participle" title="Participle">active participle</a> of the same verb form, and means "submitter (to God)" or "one who surrenders (to God)". The word <i>Islam</i> ("submission") sometimes has distinct connotations in its various occurrences in the <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a>. Some verses stress the quality of Islam as an internal spiritual state: "Whoever God wills to guide, He opens their heart to Islam."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MULTIPLE-REFERENCES2_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-MULTIPLE-REFERENCES2-45">[i]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGardetJomier2012_44-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGardetJomier2012-44">[43]</a></sup> The word <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">silm</i></span> (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø³ÙÙÙÙ</span></span>) in Arabic means both peace and also the religion of Islam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CA_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-CA-46">[44]</a></sup> A common linguistic phrase demonstrating its usage is "he entered into <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">as-silm</i></span>" (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø¯ÙØ®ÙÙÙ ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØ³ÙÙÙÙÙÙ</span></span>) which means "he entered into Islam," with a connotation of finding peace by submitting one's will to the <a href="/wiki/Predestination_in_Islam" title="Predestination in Islam">Will</a> of God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CA_46-1"><a href="#cite_note-CA-46">[44]</a></sup> The word <i>Islam</i> can be used in a linguistic sense of submission or in a technical sense of the religion of Islam, which also is called <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">as-silm</i></span> which means peace.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CA_46-2"><a href="#cite_note-CA-46">[44]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Hadith_of_Gabriel" title="Hadith of Gabriel">Hadith of Gabriel</a>, <i>Islam</i> is presented as one part of a triad that also includes <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Iman_(Islam)" title="Iman (Islam)">imÄn</a></i></span> (faith), and <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Ihsan" title="Ihsan">ihsÄn</a></i></span> (excellence).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito2000[httpsarchiveorgdetailsoxfordhistoryofi00johnpage76_76â77]_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito2000[httpsarchiveorgdetailsoxfordhistoryofi00johnpage76_76â77]-47">[45]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[46]</a></sup>
</p><p>Islam itself was historically called <a href="/wiki/Mohammedan" title="Mohammedan"><i>Mohammedanism</i></a> in the <a href="/wiki/English-speaking_world" title="English-speaking world">English-speaking world</a>. This term has fallen out of use and is sometimes said to be <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Religious_offence" title="Religious offence">offensive</a>, as it suggests that a human being, rather than God, is central to Muslims' religion, parallel to <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Buddha</a> in <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[47]</a></sup> Some authors, however, continue to use the term <i>Mohammedanism</i> as a <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/technical_term" title="wikt:technical term">technical term</a> for the religious system as opposed to the <a href="/wiki/Theology" title="Theology">theological</a> concept of Islam that exists within that system.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Articles_of_faith">Articles of faith</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Aqidah" title="Aqidah">Aqidah</a> and <a href="/wiki/Iman_(Islam)" title="Iman (Islam)">Iman</a></div>
<p>The Islamic <a href="/wiki/Creed" title="Creed">creed</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Aqidah" title="Aqidah">aqidah</a></i>) requires belief in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iman_(concept)#The_six_articles_of_the_Islamic_faith" title="Iman (concept)">six articles</a>: God, angels, books, prophets, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Day_of_Resurrection" title="Day of Resurrection">Day of Resurrection</a> and in the divine decree.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="God">God</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/God_in_Islam" title="God in Islam">God in Islam</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1045330069" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="sidebar sidebar-collapse nomobile nowraplinks plainlist"><tbody><tr><td class="sidebar-pretitle" style="background: #dcf5dc;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Basmala.svg" title="Bismillahir Rahmanir Rahim"><img alt="Bismillahir Rahmanir Rahim" data-file-height="119" data-file-width="608" decoding="async" height="35" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Basmala.svg/180px-Basmala.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Basmala.svg/270px-Basmala.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Basmala.svg/360px-Basmala.svg.png 2x" width="180"/></a><br/> Part of <a href="/wiki/Category:Allah" title="Category:Allah">a series</a> on <a class="mw-selflink selflink">Islam</a></td></tr><tr><th class="sidebar-title-with-pretitle" style="background: #dcf5dc;"><a href="/wiki/God_in_Islam" title="God in Islam">God in Islam</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-image" style="padding:0.6em;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Allah_calligraphy.svg" title='"Allah" in Arabic calligraphy'><img alt='"Allah" in Arabic calligraphy' data-file-height="432" data-file-width="432" decoding="async" height="185" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Allah_calligraphy.svg/185px-Allah_calligraphy.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Allah_calligraphy.svg/278px-Allah_calligraphy.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Allah_calligraphy.svg/370px-Allah_calligraphy.svg.png 2x" width="185"/></a><div class="sidebar-caption"><i><a href="/wiki/Allah" title="Allah">Allah</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jalla_Jalaluhu" title="Jalla Jalaluhu"> Jalla JalÄlah</a></i><br/>in <a href="/wiki/Islamic_calligraphy" title="Islamic calligraphy">Arabic calligraphy</a></div></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content" style="padding:2px 0px;">
<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="background: #dcf5dc;;background: #dcf5dc;padding:0.1em 0.2em;text-align:center;">List</div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content" style="border-bottom:1px solid #aaa;">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Allah" title="Allah">Allah</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Names_of_God_in_Islam" title="Names of God in Islam">Names</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Allah#Phrases_and_expressions" title="Allah">Phrases and expressions</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Schools_of_Islamic_theology" title="Schools of Islamic theology">Theology</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tawhid" title="Tawhid">Oneness</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Aqidah" title="Aqidah">Islamic creed</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tanzih" title="Tanzih">Transcendence</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ta%27til" title="Ta'til">Denial of Divine attributes</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tashbih" title="Tashbih">Anthropomorphism</a></li></ul></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-below" style="border-top:1px solid #dcf5dc;border-bottom:1px solid #dcf5dc;padding-bottom:0.4em;">
<img alt="" class="noviewer" data-file-height="215" data-file-width="206" decoding="async" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Allah-green.svg/15px-Allah-green.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Allah-green.svg/23px-Allah-green.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Allah-green.svg/31px-Allah-green.svg.png 2x" width="15"/>Â <a href="/wiki/Portal:Islam" title="Portal:Islam">Islam portal</a> â¢ <a href="/wiki/Category:Allah" title="Category:Allah">Category</a></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Allah" title="Template:Allah"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Allah" title="Template talk:Allah"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Allah&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The central concept of Islam is <i><a href="/wiki/Tawhid" title="Tawhid">tawá¸¥Ä«d</a></i> (Arabic: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">ØªÙØ­ÙØ¯</span>), the oneness of God. Usually thought of as a <i>precise <a href="/wiki/Monotheism" title="Monotheism">monotheism</a></i>, but also <a href="/wiki/Panentheism" title="Panentheism">panentheistic</a> in Islamic mystical teachings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[48]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[49]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[50]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[51]</a></sup> God is seen as incomparable and without partners such as in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_Trinity" title="Christian Trinity">Christian Trinity</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[52]</a></sup> and associating partners to God or attributing God's attributes to others is seen as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Idolatory" title="Idolatory">idolatory</a>, called <a href="/wiki/Shirk_(Islam)" title="Shirk (Islam)"><i>shirk</i></a>. God is seen as transcendent of creation and so is beyond comprehension. Thus, Muslims are not <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iconodule" title="Iconodule">iconodules</a> and do not attribute forms to God. God is instead described and referred to by several <a href="/wiki/Names_of_God_in_Islam" title="Names of God in Islam">names or attributes</a>, the most common being <i>Ar-RahmÄn</i> (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙØ§Ù</span></span>) meaning "The Entirely Merciful," and <i>Ar-RahÄ«m</i> (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ</span></span>) meaning "The Especially Merciful" which are invoked at the beginning of most chapters of the Quran.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ben2_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ben2-55">[53]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[54]</a></sup>
</p><p>Islam teaches that the creation of everything in the <a href="/wiki/Universe" title="Universe">universe</a> was brought into being by God's command as expressed by the wording, "<a href="/wiki/Be,_and_it_is" title="Be, and it is">Be, and it is</a>,"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[ii]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:5_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-:5-58">[55]</a></sup> and that the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Purpose_of_life" title="Purpose of life">purpose of existence</a> is to worship God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[56]</a></sup> He is viewed as a personal god<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:5_58-1"><a href="#cite_note-:5-58">[55]</a></sup> and there are no intermediaries, such as <a href="/wiki/Clergy" title="Clergy">clergy</a>, to contact God. Consciousness and awareness of God is referred to as <a href="/wiki/Taqwa" title="Taqwa">Taqwa</a>. <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All%C4%81h" title="AllÄh">AllÄh</a></i> is a term with no <a href="/wiki/Plural" title="Plural">plural</a> or <a href="/wiki/Gender" title="Gender">gender</a> being ascribed to it and is also used by Muslims and Arabic-speaking Christians and Jews in reference to God, whereas <i><span title="ISO 233 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%CA%BEil%C4%81h" title="Ê¾ilÄh">Ê¾ilÄh</a></i></span></i> (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø¥ÙÙ</span></span>) is a term used for a deity or a god in general.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[57]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[59]</a></sup> Other non-Arab Muslims might use different names as much as Allah, for instance <span title="Turkish-language text"><i lang="tr">TanrÄ±</i></span> in Turkish or <span title="Persian-language romanization"><i lang="fa-Latn">KhodÄ</i></span> in Persian.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Angels">Angels</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Angels_in_Islam" title="Angels in Islam">Angels in Islam</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rashid_al-Din_Tabib_-_Jami_al-Tawarikh,_f.45v_detail_-_c._1306-15.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4374" data-file-width="5877" decoding="async" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Rashid_al-Din_Tabib_-_Jami_al-Tawarikh%2C_f.45v_detail_-_c._1306-15.png/220px-Rashid_al-Din_Tabib_-_Jami_al-Tawarikh%2C_f.45v_detail_-_c._1306-15.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Rashid_al-Din_Tabib_-_Jami_al-Tawarikh%2C_f.45v_detail_-_c._1306-15.png/330px-Rashid_al-Din_Tabib_-_Jami_al-Tawarikh%2C_f.45v_detail_-_c._1306-15.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Rashid_al-Din_Tabib_-_Jami_al-Tawarikh%2C_f.45v_detail_-_c._1306-15.png/440px-Rashid_al-Din_Tabib_-_Jami_al-Tawarikh%2C_f.45v_detail_-_c._1306-15.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Rashid_al-Din_Tabib_-_Jami_al-Tawarikh,_f.45v_detail_-_c._1306-15.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Muhammad receiving his first revelation from the angel <a href="/wiki/Gabriel" title="Gabriel">Gabriel</a>. From the manuscript <a href="/wiki/Jami%27_al-tawarikh" title="Jami' al-tawarikh">Jami' al-Tawarikh</a> by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rashid-al-Din_Hamadani" title="Rashid-al-Din Hamadani">Rashid-al-Din Hamadani</a>, 1307.</div></div></div>
<p>Angels (Arabic: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">ÙÙÙ</span>}}, <i><span title="American Library Association â Library of Congress transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn">malak</i></span></i>) are beings described in the Quran<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBurge201523_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBurge201523-63">[60]</a></sup> and hadith.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBurge201579_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBurge201579-64">[61]</a></sup> They are described as created to worship God and also to serve other specific duties such as communicating <a href="/wiki/Revelation" title="Revelation">revelations</a> from God, recording every person's actions, and taking a person's <a href="/wiki/Soul" title="Soul">soul</a> at the time of death. They are described as being created variously from 'light' (<a href="/wiki/N%C5%ABr_(Islam)" title="NÅ«r (Islam)"><i>nÅ«r</i></a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[62]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[63]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[64]</a></sup> or 'fire' (<i>nÄr</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[65]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[66]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[67]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[68]</a></sup> Islamic angels are often represented in <a href="/wiki/Anthropomorphism" title="Anthropomorphism">anthropomorphic forms</a> combined with <a href="/wiki/Supernatural" title="Supernatural">supernatural</a> images, such as wings, being of great size or wearing heavenly articles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBurge201597â99_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBurge201597â99-72">[69]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[70]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[71]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[72]</a></sup> Common characteristics for angels are their missing needs for bodily desires, such as eating and drinking.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEÃakmak2017140_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEÃakmak2017140-76">[73]</a></sup> Some of them, such as <a href="/wiki/Gabriel" title="Gabriel">Gabriel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Michael_(archangel)" title="Michael (archangel)">Michael</a>, are mentioned by name in the Quran. Angels play a significant role in the literature about the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Isra_and_Mi%27raj" title="Isra and Mi'raj">Mi'raj</a>, where Muhammad encounters several angels during his journey through the heavens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBurge201579_64-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBurge201579-64">[61]</a></sup> Further angels have often been featured in <a href="/wiki/Islamic_eschatology" title="Islamic eschatology">Islamic eschatology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kalam" title="Kalam">theology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Islamic_philosophy" title="Islamic philosophy">philosophy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBurge201522_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBurge201522-77">[74]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Books">Books</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wahy" title="Wahy">Wahy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Islamic_holy_books" title="Islamic holy books">Islamic holy books</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Quran" title="History of the Quran">History of the Quran</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:FirstSurahKoran_(fragment).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="509" data-file-width="444" decoding="async" height="252" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/FirstSurahKoran_%28fragment%29.jpg/220px-FirstSurahKoran_%28fragment%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/FirstSurahKoran_%28fragment%29.jpg/330px-FirstSurahKoran_%28fragment%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/FirstSurahKoran_%28fragment%29.jpg/440px-FirstSurahKoran_%28fragment%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:FirstSurahKoran_(fragment).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sura" title="Sura">chapter</a> of the Quran, <i><a href="/wiki/Al-Fatiha" title="Al-Fatiha">Al-Fatiha</a></i> (<i>The Opening</i>), is seven verses</div></div></div>
<p>The Islamic holy books are the records that Muslims believe various prophets received from God through revelations, called <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wahy" title="Wahy">wahy</a></i>. Muslims believe that parts of the previously revealed scriptures, such as the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tawrat" title="Tawrat">Tawrat</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Torah" title="Torah">Torah</a>) and the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Injil" title="Injil">Injil</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Gospel_in_Islam" title="Gospel in Islam">Gospel</a>), had become <a href="/wiki/Tahrif" title="Tahrif">distorted</a>âeither in interpretation, in text, or both,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[75]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[76]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harvp|Esposito|2002b|pp=4â5_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-harvp|Esposito|2002b|pp=4â5-80">[77]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harvp|Peters|2003|p=9_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-harvp|Peters|2003|p=9-81">[78]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[79]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[80]</a></sup> while the Quran (lit. 'Recitation')<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:8_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-:8-84">[81]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[82]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[83]</a></sup> is viewed as the final, verbatim and unaltered word of God.
</p><p>Muslims believe that the verses of the Quran were revealed to Muhammad by God, through the <a href="/wiki/Archangel" title="Archangel">archangel</a> Gabriel (<i><a href="/wiki/R%C5%AB%E1%B8%A5" title="RÅ«á¸¥">JibrÄ«l</a></i>), on multiple occasions between 610Â CE and 632, the year Muhammad died.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito200417â18,_21_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito200417â18,_21-87">[84]</a></sup> While Muhammad was alive, these revelations were written down by his companions, although the prime method of transmission was orally through <a href="/wiki/Hafiz_(Quran)" title="Hafiz (Quran)">memorization</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-al_faruqi_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-al_faruqi-88">[85]</a></sup> The Quran is divided into 114 chapters (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Suras" title="Suras">suras</a>) which combined contain 6,236 verses (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ayah" title="Ayah">ÄyÄt</a></i>). The chronologically earlier chapters, revealed at <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a>, are concerned primarily with spiritual topics while the later <a href="/wiki/Medina" title="Medina">Medinan</a> chapters discuss more social and legal issues relevant to the Muslim community.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:5_58-2"><a href="#cite_note-:5-58">[55]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:8_84-1"><a href="#cite_note-:8-84">[81]</a></sup> Muslim jurists consult the <i>hadith</i> ('accounts'), or the written record of Prophet Muhammad's life, to both supplement the Quran and assist with its interpretation. The science of Quranic commentary and exegesis is known as <i><a href="/wiki/Tafsir" title="Tafsir">tafsir</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[86]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito200479â81_90-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito200479â81-90">[87]</a></sup> The set of rules governing proper <a href="/wiki/Elocution" title="Elocution">elocution</a> of recitation is called <a href="/wiki/Tajwid" title="Tajwid">tajwid</a>. In addition to its religious significance, it is widely regarded as the finest work in <a href="/wiki/Arabic_literature" title="Arabic literature">Arabic literature</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[88]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[89]</a></sup> and has influenced art and the Arabic language.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[90]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prophets">Prophets</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Prophets_and_messengers_in_Islam" title="Prophets and messengers in Islam">Prophets and messengers in Islam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sunnah" title="Sunnah">Sunnah</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hadith" title="Hadith">Hadith</a></div>

<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Medieval_Persian_manuscript_Muhammad_leads_Abraham_Moses_Jesus.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="680" data-file-width="1073" decoding="async" height="139" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Medieval_Persian_manuscript_Muhammad_leads_Abraham_Moses_Jesus.jpg/220px-Medieval_Persian_manuscript_Muhammad_leads_Abraham_Moses_Jesus.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Medieval_Persian_manuscript_Muhammad_leads_Abraham_Moses_Jesus.jpg/330px-Medieval_Persian_manuscript_Muhammad_leads_Abraham_Moses_Jesus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Medieval_Persian_manuscript_Muhammad_leads_Abraham_Moses_Jesus.jpg/440px-Medieval_Persian_manuscript_Muhammad_leads_Abraham_Moses_Jesus.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Medieval_Persian_manuscript_Muhammad_leads_Abraham_Moses_Jesus.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A Persian miniature depicts <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_in_Islam" title="Muhammad in Islam">Muhammad</a> leading <a href="/wiki/Abraham_in_Islam" title="Abraham in Islam">Abraham</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moses_in_Islam" title="Moses in Islam">Moses</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jesus_in_Islam" title="Jesus in Islam">Jesus</a> and other prophets in prayer.</div></div></div>
<p>Prophets (Arabic: <span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø£ÙØ¨ÙØ§Ø¡</span></span>, <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">anbiyÄÊ¾</i></span>) are believed to have been chosen by God to receive and preach a divine message. Additionally, a prophet delivering a new book to a nation is called a <i>rasul</i> (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø±Ø³ÙÙâ</span></span>, <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">rasÅ«l</i></span>), meaning "messenger".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[91]</a></sup> Muslims believe prophets are human and not divine. All of the prophets are said to have preached the same basic message of Islam â submission to the will of God â to various nations in the past and that this accounts for many similarities among religions. The Quran <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qisas_Al-Anbiya" title="Qisas Al-Anbiya">recounts</a> the names of numerous figures considered <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prophets_in_Islam" title="Prophets in Islam">prophets in Islam</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Adam_in_Islam" title="Adam in Islam">Adam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Noah_in_Islam" title="Noah in Islam">Noah</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abraham_in_Islam" title="Abraham in Islam">Abraham</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moses_in_Islam" title="Moses in Islam">Moses</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jesus_in_Islam" title="Jesus in Islam">Jesus</a>, among others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:5_58-3"><a href="#cite_note-:5-58">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>Muslims believe that God sent Muhammad as the final prophet ("<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seal_of_the_prophets" title="Seal of the prophets">Seal of the prophets</a>") to convey the completed message of Islam. In Islam, the "normative" example of Muhammad's life is called the <a href="/wiki/Sunnah" title="Sunnah">sunnah</a> (literally "trodden path"). Muslims are encouraged to emulate Muhammad's moral behaviors in their daily lives, and the Sunnah is seen as crucial to guiding interpretation of the Quran.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[92]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[94]</a></sup> This example is preserved in traditions known as <a href="/wiki/Hadith" title="Hadith">hadith</a>, which are accounts of his words, actions, and personal characteristics. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hadith_qudsi" title="Hadith qudsi">Hadith Qudsi</a> is a sub-category of hadith, regarded as God's verbatim words quoted by Muhammad that are not part of the Quran. A hadith involves two elements: a chain of narrators, called <a href="/wiki/Hadith_studies#Traditional_importance_of_the_sanad" title="Hadith studies"><i>sanad</i></a>, and the actual wording, called <i><a href="/wiki/Hadith_studies" title="Hadith studies">matn</a></i>. There are various methodologies to classify the authenticity of hadiths, with the commonly used grading being: "authentic" or "correct" (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">ØµØ­ÙØ­</span></span>, <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Authentic_hadith" title="Authentic hadith">á¹£aá¸¥Ä«á¸¥</a></i></span>); "good", <i>hasan</i> (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø­Ø³Ù</span></span>, <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hasan_(hadith)" title="Hasan (hadith)">á¸¥asan</a></i></span>); or "weak" (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø¶Ø¹ÙÙ</span></span>, <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Da%27if" title="Da'if">á¸aÊ»Ä«f</a></i></span>), among others. The <i><a href="/wiki/Kutub_al-Sittah" title="Kutub al-Sittah">Kutub al-Sittah</a></i> are a collection of six books, regarded as the most authentic reports in <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni Islam</a>. Among them is <i><a href="/wiki/Sahih_al-Bukhari" title="Sahih al-Bukhari">Sahih al-Bukhari</a></i>, often considered by Sunnis to be one of the most <a href="/wiki/Hadith_terminology#Terminology_relating_to_the_authenticity_of_a_hadith" title="Hadith terminology">authentic</a> sources after the Quran.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Muqaddimah_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-Muqaddimah-98">[95]</a></sup> Another famous source of hadiths is known as <i><a href="/wiki/The_Four_Books" title="The Four Books">The Four Books</a></i>, which Shias consider as the most authentic hadith reference.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meri_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-Meri-99">[96]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[97]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[98]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Resurrection_and_judgment">Resurrection and judgment</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Islamic_eschatology" title="Islamic eschatology">Islamic eschatology</a></div>
<p>Belief in the "Day of Resurrection" or <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qiyamah" title="Qiyamah">Yawm al-QiyÄmah</a></i> (Arabic: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙÙÙØ§ÙØ©</span>), is also crucial for Muslims. It is believed that the time of <i>QiyÄmah</i> is preordained by God but unknown to man. The Quran and the hadith, as well as in the commentaries of <a href="/wiki/Ulama" title="Ulama">scholars</a>, describe the trials and <a href="/wiki/Great_Tribulation" title="Great Tribulation">tribulations</a> preceding and during the <i>QiyÄmah</i>. The Quran emphasizes <a href="/wiki/Universal_resurrection" title="Universal resurrection">bodily resurrection</a>, a break from the <a href="/wiki/Pre-Islamic_Arabia" title="Pre-Islamic Arabia">pre-Islamic Arabian</a> understanding of death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[99]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[100]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[101]</a></sup>
</p><p>On Yawm al-QiyÄmah, Muslims believe all humankind will be judged by their good and bad deeds and consigned to <i><a href="/wiki/Jannah" title="Jannah">Jannah</a></i> (paradise) or <i><a href="/wiki/Jahannam" title="Jahannam">Jahannam</a></i> (hell). The Quran in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Surat_al-Zalzalah" title="Surat al-Zalzalah">Surat al-Zalzalah</a> describes this as: "So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it. And whoever does an atom's weight of evil will see it." The Quran <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_views_of_sin" title="Islamic views of sin">lists several sins</a> that can condemn a person to <a href="/wiki/Hell" title="Hell">hell</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Kafir" title="Kafir">disbelief</a> in God (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">ÙÙØ±</span></span>, <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">kufr</i></span>), and dishonesty. However, the Quran makes it clear that God will forgive the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_views_on_sin" title="Islamic views on sin">sins</a> of those who repent if he wishes. Good deeds, like charity, prayer, and compassion towards animals,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[102]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito2011130_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito2011130-106">[103]</a></sup> will be rewarded with entry to heaven. Muslims view heaven as a place of joy and blessings, with Quranic references describing its features. Mystical traditions in Islam place these heavenly delights in the context of an ecstatic awareness of God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[104]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[105]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[106]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[107]</a></sup> <i>Yawm al-QiyÄmah</i> is also identified in the Quran as <i>Yawm ad-DÄ«n</i> (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØ¯ÙÙ</span></span> "Day of Religion");<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[iii]</a></sup> <i>as-SÄÊ¿ah</i> (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø§ÙØ³Ø§Ø¹Ø©</span></span> "the Last Hour");<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[iv]</a></sup> and <i><a href="/wiki/Al-Qaria" title="Al-Qaria">al-QÄriÊ¿ah</a></i> (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø§ÙÙØ§Ø±Ø¹Ø©</span></span> "The Clatterer");<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[v]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Divine_predestination">Divine predestination</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Predestination_in_Islam" title="Predestination in Islam">Predestination in Islam</a></div>
<p>The concept of <a href="/wiki/Divinity" title="Divinity">divine</a> decree and <a href="/wiki/Destiny" title="Destiny">destiny</a> in Islam (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø§ÙÙØ¶Ø§Ø¡ ÙØ§ÙÙØ¯Ø±</span>, <i><span title="DIN 31635 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn">al-qadÄÊ¾ wa l-qadar</i></span></i>) means that every matter, good or bad, is believed to have been decreed by God. <i>Al-qadar</i>, meaning "power", derives from a root that means "to measure" or "calculating".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[108]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[109]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[110]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[111]</a></sup> Muslims often express this belief in divine destiny with the phrase <a href="/wiki/Inshallah" title="Inshallah">"Insha-Allah"</a> meaning "if God wills" when speaking on future events.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[112]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[113]</a></sup> In addition to loss, gain is also seen as a test of believers â whether they would still recognize that the gain originates only from God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[114]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Acts_of_worship">Acts of worship</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Five_Pillars_of_Islam" title="Five Pillars of Islam">Five Pillars of Islam</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ibadah" title="Ibadah">Ibadah</a></div>
<p>There are five obligatory acts of worship â the <a href="/wiki/Shahada" title="Shahada">Shahada</a> declaration of faith, the five daily prayers, the <a href="/wiki/Zakat" title="Zakat">Zakat</a> alms-giving, <a href="/wiki/Fasting_during_Ramadan" title="Fasting during Ramadan">fasting during Ramadan</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Hajj" title="Hajj">Hajj</a> pilgrimage â collectively known as "The Pillars of Islam" (<i>ArkÄn al-IslÄm</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[115]</a></sup> Apart from these, Muslims also perform other supplemental religious acts.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Testimony">Testimony</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Silver_Rupee_Akbar.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="588" decoding="async" height="112" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Silver_Rupee_Akbar.jpg/220px-Silver_Rupee_Akbar.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Silver_Rupee_Akbar.jpg/330px-Silver_Rupee_Akbar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Silver_Rupee_Akbar.jpg/440px-Silver_Rupee_Akbar.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Silver_Rupee_Akbar.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Silver coin of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mughal_Emperor" title="Mughal Emperor">Mughal Emperor</a> <a href="/wiki/Akbar" title="Akbar">Akbar</a>, inscribed with the <i>Shahadah</i></div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Shahada" title="Shahada">Shahada</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Shahada" title="Shahada"><i>shahadah</i></a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENasr20033,_39,_85,_270â272_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENasr20033,_39,_85,_270â272-122">[116]</a></sup> is an <a href="/wiki/Oath" title="Oath">oath</a> declaring belief in Islam. The expanded statement is "<span title="DIN 31635 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn">Ê¾aÅ¡hadu Ê¾al-lÄ Ê¾ilÄha Ê¾illÄ-llÄhu wa Ê¾aÅ¡hadu Ê¾anna muÄ§ammadan rasÅ«lu-llÄh</i></span>" (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø£Ø´ÙØ¯ Ø£Ù ÙØ§ Ø¥ÙÙ Ø¥ÙØ§ Ø§ÙÙÙ ÙØ£Ø´ÙØ¯ Ø£Ù ÙØ­ÙØ¯Ø§Ù Ø±Ø³ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙÙ</span></span>), or, "I testify that there is no <a href="/wiki/Deity" title="Deity">deity</a> except <a href="/wiki/God_in_Islam" title="God in Islam">God</a> and I testify that Muhammad is the messenger of God."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[117]</a></sup> Islam is sometimes argued to have a very simple creed with the shahada being the premise for the rest of the religion. Non-Muslims wishing to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Convert_to_Islam" title="Convert to Islam">convert to Islam</a> are required to recite the shahada in front of witnesses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[118]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFarah1994135_125-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFarah1994135-125">[119]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[120]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prayer">Prayer</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Salah" title="Salah">Salah</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Mosque" title="Mosque">Mosque</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jumu%27ah" title="Jumu'ah">Jumu'ah</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mosque.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Mosque.jpg/220px-Mosque.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Mosque.jpg/330px-Mosque.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Mosque.jpg/440px-Mosque.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mosque.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Muslim men <a href="/wiki/Prostration" title="Prostration">prostrating</a> in prayer, at the <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Mosque" title="Umayyad Mosque">Umayyad Mosque</a>, <a href="/wiki/Damascus" title="Damascus">Damascus</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Prayer in Islam, called <a href="/wiki/Salah" title="Salah">as-salah</a> or aá¹£-á¹£alÄt (Arabic: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø§ÙØµÙØ§Ø©</span>), is seen as a personal communication with God and consists of repeating units called <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rakat" title="Rakat">rakat</a> that include <a href="/wiki/Ruku" title="Ruku">bowing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sujud" title="Sujud">prostrating</a> to God. Performing prayers five times a day is compulsory. The prayers are recited in the Arabic language and consist of verses from the Quran.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[121]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[122]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[123]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[124]</a></sup> The prayers are done in direction of the <a href="/wiki/Kaaba" title="Kaaba">Ka'bah</a>. Salah requires ritual purity, which involves <i><a href="/wiki/Wudu" title="Wudu">wudu</a></i> (ritual wash) or occasionally, such as for new converts, <i><a href="/wiki/Ghusl" title="Ghusl">ghusl</a></i> (full body ritual wash). The means used to signal the prayer time is a vocal call called the <i><a href="/wiki/Adhan" title="Adhan">adhan</a></i>.
</p><p>A <a href="/wiki/Mosque" title="Mosque">mosque</a> is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Places_of_worship" title="Places of worship">place of worship</a> for Muslims, who often refer to it by its Arabic name masjid. Although the primary purpose of the mosque is to serve as a place of prayer, it is also important to the <a href="/wiki/Ummah" title="Ummah">Muslim community</a> as a place to meet and study with the <a href="/wiki/Al-Masjid_an-Nabawi" title="Al-Masjid an-Nabawi">Masjid an-Nabawi</a> ("Prophetic Mosque") in Medina, <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>, having also served as a shelter for the poor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[125]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Minaret" title="Minaret">Minarets</a> are towers used to call the <a href="/wiki/Adhan" title="Adhan">adhan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[126]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[127]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Charity">Charity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Zakat" title="Zakat">Zakat</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Sadaqah" title="Sadaqah">Sadaqah</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Zakat" title="Zakat">ZakÄt</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø²ÙØ§Ø©</span></span>, <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">zakÄh</i></span>) is a means of <a href="/wiki/Welfare" title="Welfare">welfare</a> in a Muslim society, characterized by the giving of a fixed portion (2.5% annually)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AhmedGianci_134-0"><a href="#cite_note-AhmedGianci-134">[128]</a></sup> of <a href="/wiki/Financial_capital" title="Financial capital">accumulated wealth</a> by those who can afford it to help the poor or needy, such as for freeing captives, those in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bonded_labour" title="Bonded labour">debt</a>, or for (stranded) travellers, and for those employed to collect zakat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[129]</a></sup> It is considered a religious obligation that the well-off owe to the needy because their wealth is seen as a "trust from God's bounty" and is seen as a "purification" of one's excess wealth. Conservative estimates of annual zakat are that it amounts to 15 times global humanitarian aid contributions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[130]</a></sup> <i>Sadaqah</i>, as opposed to Zakat, is a much encouraged <a href="/wiki/Supererogation" title="Supererogation">supererogatory</a> charity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[131]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStefon2010[httpsarchiveorgdetailsislamicbeliefspr0000stefpage72_72]_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStefon2010[httpsarchiveorgdetailsislamicbeliefspr0000stefpage72_72]-138">[132]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Waqf" title="Waqf">waqf</a> is a perpetual <a href="/wiki/Charitable_trust" title="Charitable trust">charitable trust</a>, which financed hospitals and schools in Muslim societies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[133]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fasting">Fasting</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Iftar_for_Ramadhan.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1576" data-file-width="3008" decoding="async" height="115" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Iftar_for_Ramadhan.jpg/220px-Iftar_for_Ramadhan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Iftar_for_Ramadhan.jpg/330px-Iftar_for_Ramadhan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Iftar_for_Ramadhan.jpg/440px-Iftar_for_Ramadhan.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Iftar_for_Ramadhan.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A fast-breaking feast, known as <i><a href="/wiki/Iftar" title="Iftar">Iftar</a></i>, is served traditionally with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Date_(fruits)" title="Date (fruits)">dates</a>.</div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Fasting_in_Islam" title="Fasting in Islam">Fasting in Islam</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Fasting_during_Ramadan" title="Fasting during Ramadan">Fasting during Ramadan</a></div>
<p>During the month of <a href="/wiki/Ramadan" title="Ramadan">Ramadan</a>, it is obligatory for Muslims to fast. The Ramadan fast (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">ØµÙÙ</span></span>, <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">á¹£awm</i></span>) precludes food and drink, as well as other forms of consumption, such as smoking, and is performed from dawn to sunset. The fast is to encourage a feeling of nearness to God by restraining oneself for God's sake from what is otherwise permissible and to think of the needy. In addition, there are other days when fasting is supererogatory.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pilgrimage">Pilgrimage</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Hajj" title="Hajj">Hajj</a> and <a href="/wiki/Umrah" title="Umrah">Umrah</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Holiest_sites_in_Islam" title="Holiest sites in Islam">Holiest sites in Islam</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:A_packed_house_-_Flickr_-_Al_Jazeera_English.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/A_packed_house_-_Flickr_-_Al_Jazeera_English.jpg/220px-A_packed_house_-_Flickr_-_Al_Jazeera_English.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/A_packed_house_-_Flickr_-_Al_Jazeera_English.jpg/330px-A_packed_house_-_Flickr_-_Al_Jazeera_English.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/A_packed_house_-_Flickr_-_Al_Jazeera_English.jpg/440px-A_packed_house_-_Flickr_-_Al_Jazeera_English.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:A_packed_house_-_Flickr_-_Al_Jazeera_English.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Pilgrims at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_Mosque_of_Mecca" title="Great Mosque of Mecca">Great Mosque of Mecca</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Hajj" title="Hajj">Hajj</a> season</div></div></div>
<p>The obligatory Islamic <a href="/wiki/Pilgrimage" title="Pilgrimage">pilgrimage</a>, called the "<span title="American Library Association â Library of Congress transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn">á¸¥ajj</i></span>" (Arabic: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø­Ø¬</span>), is to be done at least once a lifetime by every Muslim with the means to do so during the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Islamic month</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dhu_al-Hijjah" title="Dhu al-Hijjah">Dhu al-Hijjah</a>. Rituals of the Hajj mostly imitate the story of the family of <a href="/wiki/Abraham_in_Islam" title="Abraham in Islam">Abraham</a>. Pilgrims spend a day and a night on the plains of <a href="/wiki/Mina,_Saudi_Arabia" title="Mina, Saudi Arabia">Mina</a>, then a day praying and worshipping in the plain of <a href="/wiki/Mount_Arafat" title="Mount Arafat">Mount Arafat</a>, then spending a night on the plain of <a href="/wiki/Muzdalifah" title="Muzdalifah">Muzdalifah</a>; then moving to <a href="/wiki/Jamaraat_Bridge" title="Jamaraat Bridge">Jamarat</a>, symbolically <a href="/wiki/Stoning_of_the_Devil" title="Stoning of the Devil">stoning the Devil</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[134]</a></sup> then going to the city of <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a> and walking seven times around the <a href="/wiki/Kaaba" title="Kaaba">Kaaba</a>, which Muslims believe Abraham built as a place of worship, then walking seven times between <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Al-Safa_and_Al-Marwah" title="Al-Safa and Al-Marwah">Mount Safa</a> and Mount Marwah recounting the steps of Abraham's wife, <a href="/wiki/Hagar" title="Hagar">Hagar</a>, while she was looking for water for her baby <a href="/wiki/Ishmael_in_Islam" title="Ishmael in Islam">Ishmael</a> in the desert before Mecca developed into a settlement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[135]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[136]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[137]</a></sup> All Muslim men should wear only two simple white unstitched pieces of cloth called <a href="/wiki/Ihram_clothing" title="Ihram clothing">ihram</a>, intended to bring continuity through generations and uniformity among pilgrims despite class or origin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[138]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[139]</a></sup> Another form of pilgrimage, <i>umrah</i>, is supererogatory and can be undertaken at any time of the year. <a href="/wiki/Medina" title="Medina">Medina</a> is also a site of Islamic pilgrimage and <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>, the city of many Islamic prophets, contains the <a href="/wiki/Temple_Mount" title="Temple Mount">Al-Aqsa Mosque</a>, which used to be the <a href="/wiki/Qibla" title="Qibla">direction of prayer</a> before Mecca.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Quranic_recitation_and_memorization">Quranic recitation and memorization</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Quran#Recitation" title="Quran">Quran Â§Â Recitation</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Men_reading_the_Koran_in_Umayyad_Mosque,_Damascus,_Syria.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1875" data-file-width="2813" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Men_reading_the_Koran_in_Umayyad_Mosque%2C_Damascus%2C_Syria.jpg/220px-Men_reading_the_Koran_in_Umayyad_Mosque%2C_Damascus%2C_Syria.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Men_reading_the_Koran_in_Umayyad_Mosque%2C_Damascus%2C_Syria.jpg/330px-Men_reading_the_Koran_in_Umayyad_Mosque%2C_Damascus%2C_Syria.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Men_reading_the_Koran_in_Umayyad_Mosque%2C_Damascus%2C_Syria.jpg/440px-Men_reading_the_Koran_in_Umayyad_Mosque%2C_Damascus%2C_Syria.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Men_reading_the_Koran_in_Umayyad_Mosque,_Damascus,_Syria.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Muslim men reading the Quran</div></div></div>
<p>Muslims recite and memorize the whole or parts of the Quran as acts of virtue. Reciting the Quran with elocution (<i>tajwid</i>) has been described as an excellent act of worship.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENigosian2004[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidmy7hnALd_NkCpgPA70_70]_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENigosian2004[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidmy7hnALd_NkCpgPA70_70]-146">[140]</a></sup> Pious Muslims recite the whole Quran during the month of Ramadan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStefon2010[httpsarchiveorgdetailsislamicbeliefspr0000stefpage42_42â43]_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStefon2010[httpsarchiveorgdetailsislamicbeliefspr0000stefpage42_42â43]-147">[141]</a></sup> In Muslim societies, any social program generally begins with the recitation of the Quran.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStefon2010[httpsarchiveorgdetailsislamicbeliefspr0000stefpage42_42â43]_147-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStefon2010[httpsarchiveorgdetailsislamicbeliefspr0000stefpage42_42â43]-147">[141]</a></sup> One who has memorized the whole Quran is called a hafiz ("memorizer") who, it is said, will be able to intercede for ten people on the Last Judgment Day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENigosian2004[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidmy7hnALd_NkCpgPA70_70]_146-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENigosian2004[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidmy7hnALd_NkCpgPA70_70]-146">[140]</a></sup> Apart from this, almost every Muslim memorizes some portion of the Quran because they need to recite it during their prayers.
</p>
