<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Supplication_and_remembrance">Supplication and remembrance</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Dua" title="Dua">Dua</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dhikr" title="Dhikr">Dhikr</a></div>
<p>Supplication to God, called in Arabic <i>ad-duÊ¿ÄÊ¾</i> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø§ÙØ¯Ø¹Ø§Ø¡</span> Â <small>IPA:Â </small><span class="IPA" lang="ar-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Arabic" title="Help:IPA/Arabic">[duËÊÃ¦ËÊ]</a></span>) has its own etiquette such as <a href="/wiki/Raising_hands_in_dua" title="Raising hands in dua">raising hands</a> as if begging or invoking with an extended index finger.
</p><p>Remebrance of God (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø°ÙØ±</span></span>, <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">Dhikr'</i></span>) refers to phrases repeated referencing God. Commonly, this includes Tahmid, declaring <a href="/wiki/Alhamdulillah" title="Alhamdulillah">praise be due to God</a> (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø§ÙØ­ÙØ¯ ÙÙÙ</span></span>, <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">al-á¸¤amdu lillÄh</i></span>) during prayer or when feeling thankful, <a href="/wiki/Tasbih" title="Tasbih">Tasbih</a>, declaring glory to God during prayer or when in awe of something and saying '<a href="/wiki/Basmala" title="Basmala">in the name of God</a>' (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø¨Ø³ÙÙØ©</span></span>, <span title="American Library Association â Library of Congress transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn">basmalah</i></span>) before starting an act such as eating.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Islam" title="History of Islam">History of Islam</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a chronological guide, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Islamic_history" title="Timeline of Islamic history">Timeline of Islamic history</a>.</div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Muslim_empires_and_dynasties" title="List of Muslim empires and dynasties">List of Muslim empires and dynasties</a></div>
<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:1008px"><div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Madina_Haram_at_evening.jpg" title="A panoramic view of Al-Masjid al-Nabawi (the Mosque of the Prophet) in Medina, Hejaz region, today's Saudi Arabia, the second most sacred Mosque in Islam"><img alt="" data-file-height="475" data-file-width="2853" decoding="async" height="166" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Madina_Haram_at_evening.jpg/1000px-Madina_Haram_at_evening.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Madina_Haram_at_evening.jpg/1500px-Madina_Haram_at_evening.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Madina_Haram_at_evening.jpg/2000px-Madina_Haram_at_evening.jpg 2x" width="1000"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:center"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Madina_Haram_at_evening.jpg" title="File:Madina Haram at evening.jpg"> </a></div>A panoramic view of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Al-Masjid_al-Nabawi" title="Al-Masjid al-Nabawi">Al-Masjid al-Nabawi</a> (the Mosque of the Prophet) in <a href="/wiki/Medina" title="Medina">Medina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hejaz" title="Hejaz">Hejaz</a> region, today's Saudi Arabia, the second most sacred Mosque in Islam</div></div></div>
<h3><span id="Muhammad_.28610.E2.80.93632.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Muhammad_(610â632)">Muhammad (610â632)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1045330069" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="sidebar sidebar-collapse nomobile"><tbody><tr><td class="sidebar-pretitle" style="background-color:#dcf5dc;">Part of <a href="/wiki/Category:Muhammad" title="Category:Muhammad">a series</a> on</td></tr><tr><th class="sidebar-title-with-pretitle" style="background-color:#dcf5dc;"><a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-image"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D9%85%D8%AD%D9%85%D8%AF_%D8%B5%D9%84%D9%89_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%84%D9%87_%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A%D9%87_%D9%88%D8%B3%D9%84%D9%85.svg"><img alt="Muhammad circular symbol" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="500" decoding="async" height="230" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/%D9%85%D8%AD%D9%85%D8%AF_%D8%B5%D9%84%D9%89_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%84%D9%87_%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A%D9%87_%D9%88%D8%B3%D9%84%D9%85.svg/230px-%D9%85%D8%AD%D9%85%D8%AF_%D8%B5%D9%84%D9%89_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%84%D9%87_%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A%D9%87_%D9%88%D8%B3%D9%84%D9%85.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/%D9%85%D8%AD%D9%85%D8%AF_%D8%B5%D9%84%D9%89_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%84%D9%87_%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A%D9%87_%D9%88%D8%B3%D9%84%D9%85.svg/345px-%D9%85%D8%AD%D9%85%D8%AF_%D8%B5%D9%84%D9%89_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%84%D9%87_%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A%D9%87_%D9%88%D8%B3%D9%84%D9%85.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/%D9%85%D8%AD%D9%85%D8%AF_%D8%B5%D9%84%D9%89_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%84%D9%87_%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A%D9%87_%D9%88%D8%B3%D9%84%D9%85.svg/460px-%D9%85%D8%AD%D9%85%D8%AF_%D8%B5%D9%84%D9%89_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%84%D9%87_%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A%D9%87_%D9%88%D8%B3%D9%84%D9%85.svg.png 2x" width="230"/></a></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content hlist">

<ul><li><img alt="" class="noviewer" data-file-height="215" data-file-width="206" decoding="async" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Allah-green.svg/15px-Allah-green.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Allah-green.svg/23px-Allah-green.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Allah-green.svg/31px-Allah-green.svg.png 2x" width="15"/>Â <a href="/wiki/Portal:Islam" title="Portal:Islam">Islam portal</a></li>
<li><img alt="" class="noviewer" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="1911" decoding="async" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/69/P_vip.svg/16px-P_vip.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/69/P_vip.svg/24px-P_vip.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/69/P_vip.svg/31px-P_vip.svg.png 2x" width="16"/>Â <a href="/wiki/Portal:Biography" title="Portal:Biography">Biography portal</a></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar" style="background:white; padding:0 5px"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Muhammad" title="Template:Muhammad"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Muhammad" title="Template talk:Muhammad"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Muhammad&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a> and <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_in_Islam" title="Muhammad in Islam">Muhammad in Islam</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Early_social_changes_under_Islam" title="Early social changes under Islam">Early social changes under Islam</a></div>
<p>Born in <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a> in 571, Muhammad was orphaned early in life. New trade routes rapidly transformed Meccan society from a semi-bedouin society to a commercial urban society, leaving out weaker segments of society without protection. He acquired the nickname "<a href="/wiki/Amin_(name)" title="Amin (name)">trustworthy</a>" (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø§ÙØ§ÙÙÙ</span>), <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito20106_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito20106-148">[142]</a></sup> and was sought after as a bank to safeguard valuables and an impartial arbitrator. Affected by the ills of society and after becoming financially secure through marrying his employer, the businesswoman <a href="/wiki/Khadija_bint_Khuwaylid" title="Khadija bint Khuwaylid">Khadija</a>, he began retreating to a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cave_of_Hira" title="Cave of Hira">cave</a> to contemplate. During the last 22 years of his life, beginning at age 40 in 610 <a href="/wiki/Common_Era" title="Common Era">CE</a>, Muhammad reported receiving revelations from God, conveyed to him through the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holy_Spirit_(Islam)" title="Holy Spirit (Islam)">archangel Gabriel</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:04_149-0"><a href="#cite_note-:04-149">[143]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[144]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[145]</a></sup> thus becoming the seal of the prophets sent to the mankind according to Islamic tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[146]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harvp|Esposito|2002b|pp=4â5_80-1"><a href="#cite_note-harvp|Esposito|2002b|pp=4â5-80">[77]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harvp|Peters|2003|p=9_81-1"><a href="#cite_note-harvp|Peters|2003|p=9-81">[78]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[147]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:04_149-1"><a href="#cite_note-:04-149">[143]</a></sup>
</p><p>During this time, <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_in_Mecca" title="Muhammad in Mecca">while in Mecca, Muhammad</a> preached first in secret and then in public, imploring his listeners to abandon <a href="/wiki/Polytheism" title="Polytheism">polytheism</a> and worship one God. Many early converts to Islam were women, the poor, foreigners, and slaves like the first <a href="/wiki/Muezzin" title="Muezzin">muezzin</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bilal_ibn_Rabah_al-Habashi" title="Bilal ibn Rabah al-Habashi">Bilal ibn Rabah al-Habashi</a>. The Meccan elite profited from the pilgrimages to the idols of the Kaaba and felt Muhammad was destabilizing their social order by preaching about one God, and that in the process he gave questionable ideas to the poor and slaves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[148]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[149]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[150]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[151]</a></sup> Muhammad, who was accused of being a poet, a madman or possessed, presented the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Challenge_of_the_Quran" title="Challenge of the Quran">challenge of the Quran</a> to imitate the like of the Quran in order to disprove him. The Meccan authorities persecuted Muhammad and his followers, including a boycott and banishment of Muhammad and his clan to starve them into withdrawing their protection of him. This resulted in the <a href="/wiki/Migration_to_Abyssinia" title="Migration to Abyssinia">Migration to Abyssinia</a> of some Muslims (to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aksumite_Empire" title="Aksumite Empire">Aksumite Empire</a>).
</p><p>After 12 years of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Muslims_by_the_Meccans" title="Persecution of Muslims by the Meccans">persecution of Muslims by the Meccans</a>, Muhammad and his <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sahaba" title="Sahaba">companions</a> performed the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hegira" title="Hegira">Hijra</a></i> ("emigration") in 622 to the city of Yathrib (current-day Medina). There, with the Medinan converts (the <i><a href="/wiki/Ansar_(Islam)" title="Ansar (Islam)">Ansar</a></i>) and the Meccan migrants (the <i><a href="/wiki/Muhajirun" title="Muhajirun">Muhajirun</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_in_Medina" title="Muhammad in Medina">Muhammad in Medina</a> established his <a href="/wiki/Theocracy" title="Theocracy">political and religious authority</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Medina" title="Constitution of Medina">Constitution of Medina</a> was signed<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[b]</a></sup> by all the tribes of Medina agreeing to defend Medina from external threats and establishing among the Muslim, Jewish, Christian, and pagan communities religious freedoms and freedom to use their own laws, security of women and the role of Medina as a sacred place barred of weapons and violence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESerjeant19784_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESerjeant19784-164">[157]</a></sup> Within a few years, two battles took place against the Meccan forces: first, the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Badr" title="Battle of Badr">Battle of Badr</a> in 624âa Muslim victoryâand then a year later, when the Meccans returned to Medina, the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Uhud" title="Battle of Uhud">Battle of Uhud</a>, which ended inconclusively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[158]</a></sup> The Arab tribes in the rest of Arabia then formed a confederation, and during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Trench" title="Battle of the Trench">Battle of the Trench</a> (MarchâAprilÂ 627) besieged Medina, intent on finishing off Islam. In 628, the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Hudaybiyyah" title="Treaty of Hudaybiyyah">Treaty of Hudaybiyyah</a> was signed between Mecca and the Muslims, but it was broken by Mecca two years later. After signing the Treaty of Hudaybiyyah, many more people converted to Islam. At the same time, Meccan trade routes were cut off as Muhammad brought surrounding desert tribes under his control.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[159]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[160]</a></sup> By 629 Muhammad was victorious in the nearly bloodless <a href="/wiki/Conquest_of_Mecca" title="Conquest of Mecca">conquest of Mecca</a>, and by the time of his death in 632 (at age 62) he had united the <a href="/wiki/Tribes_of_Arabia" title="Tribes of Arabia">tribes of Arabia</a> into a single religious <a href="/wiki/Polity" title="Polity">polity</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[161]</a></sup>
</p><p>The earliest three generations of Muslims are known as the <a href="/wiki/Salaf" title="Salaf">Salaf</a>, with the companions of Muhammad being known as the Sahaba. Many of them, such as the largest narrator of hadith <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abu_Hureyrah" title="Abu Hureyrah">Abu Hureyrah</a>, recorded and compiled what would constitute the sunnah.
</p>
<h3><span id="Caliphate_and_civil_strife_.28632.E2.80.93750.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Caliphate_and_civil_strife_(632â750)">Caliphate and civil strife (632â750)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Succession_to_Muhammad" title="Succession to Muhammad">Succession to Muhammad</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslim_conquests" title="Muslim conquests">Muslim conquests</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Event_of_Ghadir_Khumm" title="Event of Ghadir Khumm">Event of Ghadir Khumm</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saqifa" title="Saqifa">Saqifa</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mohammad_adil-Rashidun_empire-slide.gif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="580" data-file-width="1196" decoding="async" height="107" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Mohammad_adil-Rashidun_empire-slide.gif/220px-Mohammad_adil-Rashidun_empire-slide.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Mohammad_adil-Rashidun_empire-slide.gif/330px-Mohammad_adil-Rashidun_empire-slide.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Mohammad_adil-Rashidun_empire-slide.gif/440px-Mohammad_adil-Rashidun_empire-slide.gif 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mohammad_adil-Rashidun_empire-slide.gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Rashidun_Caliphate" title="Rashidun Caliphate">Rashidun</a> and <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad</a> expansion</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dome_of_the_Rock1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Dome_of_the_Rock1.jpg/220px-Dome_of_the_Rock1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Dome_of_the_Rock1.jpg/330px-Dome_of_the_Rock1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Dome_of_the_Rock1.jpg/440px-Dome_of_the_Rock1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dome_of_the_Rock1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Dome_of_the_Rock" title="Dome of the Rock">Dome of the Rock</a> built by caliph <a href="/wiki/Abd_al-Malik_ibn_Marwan" title="Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan">Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan</a>; completed at the end of the <a href="/wiki/Second_Fitna" title="Second Fitna">Second Fitna</a></div></div></div>
<p>Following Muhammad's death in 632, Muslims disagreed over who would succeed him as leader. The first successors â <a href="/wiki/Abu_Bakr" title="Abu Bakr">Abu Bakr</a>, <a href="/wiki/Umar" title="Umar">Umar</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Uthman_ibn_al-Affan" title="Uthman ibn al-Affan">Uthman ibn al-Affan</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ali_ibn_Abi_Talib" title="Ali ibn Abi Talib">Ali ibn Abi Talib</a> and sometimes <a href="/wiki/Hasan_ibn_Ali" title="Hasan ibn Ali">Hasan ibn Ali</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[162]</a></sup> â are known in Sunni Islam as <i>al-khulafÄ' ar-rÄshidÅ«n</i> ("<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rightly_Guided_Caliphs" title="Rightly Guided Caliphs">Rightly Guided Caliphs</a>").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito201040_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito201040-170">[163]</a></sup> Some tribes left Islam and rebelled under leaders who declared themselves new prophets but were crushed by Abu Bakr in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ridda_wars" title="Ridda wars">Ridda wars</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[164]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[165]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[166]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[167]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[168]</a></sup> Under Umar, the caliphate expanded rapidly as Muslims scored major victories over the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sassanid_Empire" title="Sassanid Empire">Persian</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Byzantine" title="Byzantine">Byzantine</a> empires.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[169]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harvp|Gardet|Jomier|2012_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-harvp|Gardet|Jomier|2012-177">[170]</a></sup> Local populations of Jews and indigenous Christians, persecuted as religious minorities and heretics and taxed heavily, often helped Muslims take over their lands from the Byzantines and Persians, resulting in exceptionally speedy conquests.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito201038_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito201038-178">[171]</a></sup> Uthman <a href="/wiki/Election_of_Uthman" title="Election of Uthman">was elected in 644</a>. Ali reluctantly accepted being elected the next Caliph after Uthman, whose assassination by rebels in 656 led to the <a href="/wiki/First_Fitna" title="First Fitna">First Civil War</a>. Muhammad's widow, <a href="/wiki/Aisha" title="Aisha">Aisha</a>, raised an army against Ali, asking to avenge the death of Uthman, but was defeated at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Camel" title="Battle of the Camel">Battle of the Camel</a>. Ali attempted to remove the governor of Syria, Mu'awiya, who was seen as corrupt. Mu'awiya then declared war on Ali after accusing him of being behind Uthman's death. Ali defeated him in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Siffin" title="Battle of Siffin">Battle of Siffin</a>, and then decided to arbitrate with him. This angered the <a href="/wiki/Kharijites" title="Kharijites">Kharijites</a>, an extremist sect, who felt Ali should do battle with Mu'awiya. They felt that by not fighting a sinner, Ali became a sinner as well.  The Kharijites rebelled against Ali and were defeated in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Nahrawan" title="Battle of Nahrawan">Battle of Nahrawan</a> but a Kharijite assassin later killed Ali. Subsequently, Ali's son, Hasan ibn Ali, was elected Caliph. To avoid further fighting, Hasan signed a <a href="/wiki/Hasan%E2%80%93Muawiya_treaty" title="HasanâMuawiya treaty">peace treaty</a> abdicating to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muawiyah_I" title="Muawiyah I">Mu'awiyah</a> in return for him not appointing a successor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoltLewis197767â72_179-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoltLewis197767â72-179">[172]</a></sup> Mu'awiyah began the <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_dynasty" title="Umayyad dynasty">Umayyad dynasty</a> with the appointment of his son <a href="/wiki/Yazid_I" title="Yazid I">YazidÂ I</a>. This sparked the <a href="/wiki/Second_Fitna" title="Second Fitna">Second Civil War</a>. During the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Karbala" title="Battle of Karbala">Battle of Karbala</a>, <a href="/wiki/Husayn_ibn_Ali" title="Husayn ibn Ali">Husayn ibn Ali</a> and other descendants of Muhammad were massacred by Yazid; the event has been <a href="/wiki/Ashura" title="Ashura">annually commemorated</a> by Shia ever since. Sunnis, led by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ibn_al-Zubayr" title="Ibn al-Zubayr">Ibn al-Zubayr</a>, who were opposed to the caliphate turning into a dynasty were defeated in the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Mecca_(692)" title="Siege of Mecca (692)">Siege of Mecca</a>. These disputes over leadership would give rise to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sunni" title="Sunni">Sunni</a>-<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shia" title="Shia">Shia</a> schism,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-20160103_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-20160103-180">[173]</a></sup> with the Shia believing leadership belonging to Ali and the family of Muhammad called the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ahl_al-bayt" title="Ahl al-bayt">ahl al-bayt</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWaines200346_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWaines200346-181">[174]</a></sup> Meanwhile, the Kharijites disagreed with Uthman and Ali. <a href="/wiki/Political_quietism_in_Islam" title="Political quietism in Islam">Quietist forms</a> led to the emergence of the third largest denomination in Islam, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ibadiyya" title="Ibadiyya">Ibadiyya</a>.
</p><p>Abu Bakr's leadership oversaw the beginning of the compilation of the Qur'an. The Caliph <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Umar_ibn_Abd_al-Aziz" title="Umar ibn Abd al-Aziz">Umar ibn Abd al-Aziz</a> set up the influential committee, <a href="/wiki/The_Seven_Fuqaha_of_Medina" title="The Seven Fuqaha of Medina">The Seven Fuqaha of Medina</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIsmÄÊ»Ä«l_ibn_Ê»Umar_Ibn_KathÄ«r2012505_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsmÄÊ»Ä«l_ibn_Ê»Umar_Ibn_KathÄ«r2012505-182">[175]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[176]</a></sup> headed by <a href="/wiki/Qasim_ibn_Muhammad_ibn_Abi_Bakr" title="Qasim ibn Muhammad ibn Abi Bakr">Qasim ibn Muhammad ibn Abi Bakr</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIsmÄÊ»Ä«l_ibn_Ê»Umar_Ibn_KathÄ«r2012522_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsmÄÊ»Ä«l_ibn_Ê»Umar_Ibn_KathÄ«r2012522-184">[177]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Malik_ibn_Anas" title="Malik ibn Anas">Malik ibn Anas</a> wrote one of the earliest books on Islamic jurisprudence, the <i><a href="/wiki/Muwatta_Imam_Malik" title="Muwatta Imam Malik">Muwatta</a></i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[178]</a></sup> as a consensus of the opinion of those jurists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[179]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[180]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[181]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kharijites" title="Kharijites">Kharijites</a> believed there is no compromised middle ground between good and evil, and any Muslim who commits a grave sin becomes an unbeliever. The term is also used to refer to later groups such as <a href="/wiki/Islamic_State" title="Islamic State">Isis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[182]</a></sup> Conversely, an early sect, the <a href="/wiki/Murji%27ah" title="Murji'ah">Murji'ah</a> taught that people's righteousness could be judged by God alone. Therefore, wrongdoers might be considered misguided, but not denounced as unbelievers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlankinship200843_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlankinship200843-190">[183]</a></sup>  This attitude came to prevail into mainstream Islamic beliefs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito201087_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito201087-191">[184]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Umayyad dynasty conquered the <a href="/wiki/Maghreb" title="Maghreb">Maghreb</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gallia_Narbonensis" title="Gallia Narbonensis">Narbonnese Gaul</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sindh" title="Sindh">Sindh</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[185]</a></sup> The Umayyads struggled with a lack of legitimacy and relied on a heavily patronized military.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito201045_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito201045-193">[186]</a></sup> Since the jizya tax was a tax paid by non-Muslims which exempted them from military service, the Umayyads denied recognizing the conversion of non-Arabs as it reduced revenue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito201087_191-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito201087-191">[184]</a></sup> While the Rashidun Caliphate emphasized austerity, with Umar even requiring an inventory of each official's possessions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[187]</a></sup> Umayyad luxury bred dissatisfaction among the pious.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito201087_191-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito201087-191">[184]</a></sup> The Kharijites led the <a href="/wiki/Berber_Revolt" title="Berber Revolt">Berber Revolt</a> leading to the first Muslim states independent of the Caliphate. In the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abbasid_revolution" title="Abbasid revolution">Abbasid revolution</a>, non-Arab converts (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mawali" title="Mawali">mawali</a></i>), Arab clans pushed aside by the Umayyad clan, and some Shi'a rallied and overthrew the Umayyads, inaugurating the more cosmopolitan Abbasid dynasty in 750.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELapidus200256_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELapidus200256-195">[188]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewis199371â83_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewis199371â83-196">[189]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Classical_era_.28750.E2.80.931258.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Classical_era_(750â1258)">Classical era (750â1258)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Hadith_studies" title="Hadith studies">Hadith studies</a> and <a href="/wiki/Islamic_philosophy" title="Islamic philosophy">Islamic philosophy</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Islamic_world_contributions_to_Medieval_Europe" title="Islamic world contributions to Medieval Europe">Islamic world contributions to Medieval Europe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Turco-Persian_tradition" title="Turco-Persian tradition">Turco-Persian tradition</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cheshm_manuscript.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="450" decoding="async" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Cheshm_manuscript.jpg/220px-Cheshm_manuscript.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Cheshm_manuscript.jpg/330px-Cheshm_manuscript.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Cheshm_manuscript.jpg/440px-Cheshm_manuscript.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cheshm_manuscript.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The eye, according to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hunain_ibn_Ishaq" title="Hunain ibn Ishaq">Hunain ibn Ishaq</a> from a manuscript dated c. 1200</div></div></div>
<p>Al-Shafi'i codified a method to determine the reliability of hadith.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELapidus200286_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELapidus200286-197">[190]</a></sup> During the early Abbasid era, scholars such as <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_al-Bukhari" title="Muhammad al-Bukhari">Bukhari</a> and <a href="/wiki/Muslim_ibn_al-Hajjaj" title="Muslim ibn al-Hajjaj">Muslim</a> compiled the major <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Six_major_Hadith_collections" title="Six major Hadith collections">Sunni hadith collections</a> while scholars like <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_ibn_Ya%27qub_al-Kulayni" title="Muhammad ibn Ya'qub al-Kulayni">Al-Kulayni</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Babawayh" title="Ibn Babawayh">Ibn Babawayh</a> compiled major Shia hadith collections. The four Sunni <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Madh%27hab" title="Madh'hab">Madh'habs</a>, the Hanafi, Hanbali, Maliki, and Shafi'i, were established around the teachings of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ab%C5%AB_%E1%B8%A4an%C4%ABfa" title="AbÅ« á¸¤anÄ«fa">AbÅ« á¸¤anÄ«fa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ahmad_ibn_Hanbal" title="Ahmad ibn Hanbal">Ahmad ibn Hanbal</a>, Malik ibn Anas and <a href="/wiki/Al-Shafi%27i" title="Al-Shafi'i">al-Shafi'i</a>. In contrast, the teachings of <a href="/wiki/Ja%27far_al-Sadiq" title="Ja'far al-Sadiq">Ja'far al-Sadiq</a> formed the <a href="/wiki/Ja%27fari_jurisprudence" title="Ja'fari jurisprudence">Ja'fari jurisprudence</a>. In the 9thÂ century <a href="/wiki/Al-Tabari" title="Al-Tabari">Al-Tabari</a> completed the first commentary of the Quran, that became one of the most cited commentaries in Sunni Islam, the <i><a href="/wiki/Tafsir_al-Tabari" title="Tafsir al-Tabari">Tafsir al-Tabari</a></i>. Some Muslims began questioning the piety of indulgence in worldly life and emphasized poverty, humility, and avoidance of sin based on renunciation of bodily desires. Ascetics such as Hasan al-Basri would inspire a movement that would evolve into <i>Tasawwuf</i> or Sufism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB-Sufism_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-EB-Sufism-198">[191]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELapidus200290,_91_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELapidus200290,_91-199">[192]</a></sup>
</p><p>At this time, theological problems, notably on free will, were prominently tackled, with Hasan al Basri holding that although God knows people's actions, good and evil come from abuse of free will and the <a href="/wiki/Iblis" title="Iblis">devil</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlankinship200838â39_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlankinship200838â39-200">[193]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[c]</a></sup> Greek rationalist philosophy influenced a speculative school of thought known as <a href="/wiki/Mu%CA%BFtazila" title="MuÊ¿tazila">MuÊ¿tazila</a>, first originated by <a href="/wiki/Wasil_ibn_Ata" title="Wasil ibn Ata">Wasil ibn Ata</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlankinship200850_203-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlankinship200850-203">[195]</a></sup> Caliphs such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mamun_al_Rashid" title="Mamun al Rashid">Mamun al Rashid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Al-Mu%27tasim" title="Al-Mu'tasim">Al-Mu'tasim</a> made it an official creed and unsuccessfully attempted to force their position on the majority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito201088_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito201088-204">[196]</a></sup> They carried out inquisitions with the traditionalist <a href="/wiki/Ahmad_ibn_Hanbal" title="Ahmad ibn Hanbal">Ahmad ibn Hanbal</a> notably refusing to conform to the Mutazila idea of the creation of the Quran and was tortured and kept in an unlit prison cell for nearly thirty months.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[197]</a></sup> However, other <a href="/wiki/Schools_of_Islamic_theology" title="Schools of Islamic theology">schools</a> of <a href="/wiki/Kalam" title="Kalam">speculative theology</a> â <a href="/wiki/Maturidi" title="Maturidi">MÄturÄ«dism</a> founded by <a href="/wiki/Abu_Mansur_al-Maturidi" title="Abu Mansur al-Maturidi">Abu Mansur al-Maturidi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ash%27ari" title="Ash'ari">Ash'ari</a> founded by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Al-Ash%27ari" title="Al-Ash'ari">Al-Ash'ari</a> â were more successful in being widely adopted. Philosophers such as <a href="/wiki/Al-Farabi" title="Al-Farabi">Al-Farabi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Avicenna" title="Avicenna">Avicenna</a> and <a href="/wiki/Averroes" title="Averroes">Averroes</a> sought to harmonize Aristotle's metaphysics within Islam, similar to later <a href="/wiki/Scholasticism" title="Scholasticism">scholasticism</a> within Christianity in Europe, and <a href="/wiki/Maimonides" title="Maimonides">Maimonides</a>' work within Judaism, while others like <a href="/wiki/Al-Ghazali" title="Al-Ghazali">Al-Ghazali</a> argued against such <a href="/wiki/Syncretism" title="Syncretism">syncretism</a> and ultimately prevailed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[198]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[199]</a></sup>
</p><p>This era is sometimes called the "<a href="/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age" title="Islamic Golden Age">Islamic Golden Age</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[200]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[201]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[202]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harvp|Gardet|Jomier|2012_177-1"><a href="#cite_note-harvp|Gardet|Jomier|2012-177">[170]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Avicenna" title="Avicenna">Avicenna</a> was a pioneer in <a href="/wiki/Medical_research" title="Medical research">experimental medicine</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jacquart,_Danielle_2008_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jacquart,_Danielle_2008-212">[204]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[205]</a></sup> and his <i><a href="/wiki/The_Canon_of_Medicine" title="The Canon of Medicine">The Canon of Medicine</a></i> was used as a standard medicinal text in the Islamic world and <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> for centuries. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rhazes" title="Rhazes">Rhazes</a> was the first to distinguish the diseases <a href="/wiki/Smallpox" title="Smallpox">smallpox</a> and <a href="/wiki/Measles" title="Measles">measles</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[206]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Public_hospital" title="Public hospital">Public hospitals</a> of the time issued the first medical diplomas to license doctors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Alatas_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-Alatas-215">[207]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[208]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ibn_al-Haytham" title="Ibn al-Haytham">Ibn al-Haytham</a> is regarded as the father of the modern <a href="/wiki/Scientific_method" title="Scientific method">scientific method</a> and often referred to as the "world's first true scientist", in particular regarding his work in <a href="/wiki/Optics" title="Optics">optics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Haq_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-Haq-217">[209]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[210]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[211]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[212]</a></sup> In engineering, the <a href="/wiki/Ban%C5%AB_M%C5%ABs%C4%81" title="BanÅ« MÅ«sÄ">BanÅ« MÅ«sÄ</a> brothers' <a href="/wiki/Automaton" title="Automaton">automatic</a> <a href="/wiki/Flute" title="Flute">flute</a> player is considered to have been the first <a href="/wiki/Program_(machine)" title="Program (machine)">programmable machine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Koetsier2_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-Koetsier2-221">[213]</a></sup> In <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_mathematics" title="Islamic mathematics">mathematics</a>, the concept of the <a href="/wiki/Algorithm" title="Algorithm">algorithm</a> is named after <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_ibn_Musa_al-Khwarizmi" title="Muhammad ibn Musa al-Khwarizmi">Muhammad ibn Musa al-Khwarizmi</a>, who is considered a founder of <a href="/wiki/Algebra" title="Algebra">algebra</a>, which is named after his book <a href="/wiki/The_Compendious_Book_on_Calculation_by_Completion_and_Balancing" title="The Compendious Book on Calculation by Completion and Balancing"><i>al-jabr</i></a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[214]</a></sup> while others developed the concept of a <a href="/wiki/Function_(mathematics)" title="Function (mathematics)">function</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[215]</a></sup> The government paid scientists the equivalent salary of professional athletes today.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ahmed_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ahmed-224">[216]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Guinness_World_Records" title="Guinness World Records">Guinness World Records</a> recognizes the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/University_of_Al_Karaouine" title="University of Al Karaouine">University of Al Karaouine</a>, founded in 859, as the world's oldest degree-granting university.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[217]</a></sup>
</p><p>The vast Abbasid empire proved impossible to hold together.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito2010150_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito2010150-226">[218]</a></sup> Soldiers established their own dynasties, such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tulunid" title="Tulunid">Tulunids</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samanid_Empire" title="Samanid Empire">Samanid</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ghaznavid" title="Ghaznavid">Ghaznavid dynasty</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[219]</a></sup> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Millennialist" title="Millennialist">millennialist</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Isma%27ili" title="Isma'ili">Isma'ili</a> Shi'a missionary movement rose with the <a href="/wiki/Fatimid_dynasty" title="Fatimid dynasty">Fatimid dynasty</a> taking control of North Africa<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[220]</a></sup> and with the <a href="/wiki/Qarmatians" title="Qarmatians">Qarmatians</a> sacking Mecca and stealing the Black Stone in their unsuccessful rebellion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[221]</a></sup> In what is called the <a href="/wiki/Shi%27a_Century" title="Shi'a Century">Shi'a Century</a>, another Ismaili group, the <a href="/wiki/Buyid_dynasty" title="Buyid dynasty">Buyid dynasty</a> conquered Baghdad and turned the Abbasids into a figurehead monarchy. The Sunni Seljuk dynasty, campaigned to <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Revival" title="Sunni Revival">reassert Sunni Islam</a> by promulgating the accumulated scholarly opinion of the time  notably with the construction of educational institutions known as <a href="/wiki/Nezamiyeh" title="Nezamiyeh">Nezamiyeh</a>, which are associated with Al-Ghazali and <a href="/wiki/Saadi_Shirazi" title="Saadi Shirazi">Saadi Shirazi</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[222]</a></sup> The Ismailis continued splintering over the legitimacy of successive imams with the <a href="/wiki/Alawites" title="Alawites">Alawites</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Druze" title="Druze">Druze</a>, offshoots of Shi'a Islam, dating to this time.
</p><p>Religious missions converted <a href="/wiki/Volga_Bulgaria" title="Volga Bulgaria">Volga Bulgaria</a> to Islam. The <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate" title="Delhi Sultanate">Delhi Sultanate</a> reached deep into the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_Subcontinent" title="Indian Subcontinent">Indian Subcontinent</a> and many converted to Islam,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[223]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[224]</a></sup> in particular <a href="/wiki/Dalit" title="Dalit">low-caste Hindus</a> whose descendents make up the vast majority of Indian Muslims.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[225]</a></sup> Many Muslims also went to <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_China" title="Islam in China">China</a> to trade, virtually dominating the import and export industry of the <a href="/wiki/Song_dynasty" title="Song dynasty">Song dynasty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-china_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-china-234">[226]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Pre-Modern_era_.281258.E2.80.9318th_century.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Pre-Modern_era_(1258â18th_century)">Pre-Modern era (1258â18th century)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Safavid_conversion_of_Iran_to_Shia_Islam" title="Safavid conversion of Iran to Shia Islam">Safavid conversion of Iran to Shia Islam</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GhazanConversionToIslam.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2009" data-file-width="1498" decoding="async" height="295" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/GhazanConversionToIslam.JPG/220px-GhazanConversionToIslam.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/GhazanConversionToIslam.JPG/330px-GhazanConversionToIslam.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/GhazanConversionToIslam.JPG/440px-GhazanConversionToIslam.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GhazanConversionToIslam.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ghazan_Khan" title="Ghazan Khan">Ghazan Khan</a>, 7<sup>th</sup> <a href="/wiki/Ilkhanate" title="Ilkhanate">Ilkhanate</a> ruler of the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_Empire" title="Mongol Empire">Mongol Empire</a>, converts to Islam</div></div></div>
<p>Through Muslim trade networks and the activity of Sufi orders, Islam spread into new areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGardetJomier2012_44-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGardetJomier2012-44">[43]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[227]</a></sup> Under the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>, Islam spread to <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Europe" title="Southeast Europe">Southeast Europe</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[228]</a></sup> Conversion to Islam, however, was not a sudden abandonment of old religious practices; rather, it was typically a matter of "assimilating Islamic rituals, cosmologies, and literatures into... local religious systems",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[229]</a></sup> as illustrated by Muhammad's appearance in <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hindu</a> folklore.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[230]</a></sup> The Turks probably found similarities between Sufi rituals and Shaman practices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEÃakmak20171425â1429_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEÃakmak20171425â1429-239">[231]</a></sup> Muslim Turks incorporated elements of <a href="/wiki/Tengrism" title="Tengrism">Turkish Shamanism beliefs</a> to Islam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[d]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEÃakmak20171425â1429_239-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEÃakmak20171425â1429-239">[231]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Islam_during_the_Ming_dynasty" title="Islam during the Ming dynasty">Muslims in China</a>, who were descended from earlier immigrants, were assimilated, sometimes by force, by adopting Chinese names and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_culture" title="Chinese culture">culture</a> while <a href="/wiki/Nanjing" title="Nanjing">Nanjing</a> became an important center of Islamic study.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[233]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[234]</a></sup>
</p><p>While cultural influence used to radiate outward from Baghdad, after the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasions_and_conquests" title="Mongol invasions and conquests">Mongol destruction</a> of the Abbasid Caliphate, Arab influence decreased.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[235]</a></sup> Iran and Central Asia, benefiting from increased cross-cultural access to East Asia under <a href="/wiki/Pax_Mongolica" title="Pax Mongolica">Mongol rule</a>, flourished and developed more distinctively from Arab influence, such as the <a href="/wiki/Timurid_Renaissance" title="Timurid Renaissance">Timurid Renaissance</a> under the <a href="/wiki/Timurid_dynasty" title="Timurid dynasty">Timurid dynasty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[236]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nasir_al-Din_al-Tusi" title="Nasir al-Din al-Tusi">Nasir al-Din al-Tusi</a> (1201â1274) proposed the <a href="/wiki/Tusi_couple" title="Tusi couple">mathematical model</a> that was later adopted by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Copernicus" title="Copernicus">Copernicus</a> unrevised in his heliocentric model and <a href="/wiki/Jamsh%C4%ABd_al-K%C4%81sh%C4%AB" title="JamshÄ«d al-KÄshÄ«">JamshÄ«d al-KÄshÄ«</a>'s estimate of <a href="/wiki/Pi" title="Pi">pi</a> would not be surpassed for 180 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[237]</a></sup> Many Muslim dynasties in India chose Persian as their court language.
</p><p>The introduction of gunpowder weapons led to the rise of large centralized states and the Muslim <a href="/wiki/Gunpowder_empires" title="Gunpowder empires">Gunpowder empires</a> consolidated much of the previously splintered territories. The <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Caliphate" title="Ottoman Caliphate">caliphate</a> was claimed by the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_dynasty" title="Ottoman dynasty">Ottoman dynasty</a> of the Ottoman Empire since <a href="/wiki/Murad_I" title="Murad I">MuradÂ I</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_conquest_of_Adrianople" title="Ottoman conquest of Adrianople">conquest of Edirne</a> in 1362,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[238]</a></sup> and its claims were strengthened in 1517 as <a href="/wiki/Selim_I" title="Selim I">SelimÂ I</a> became the <a href="/wiki/Custodian_of_the_Two_Holy_Mosques" title="Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques">ruler of Mecca and Medina</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[239]</a></sup> The Shia <a href="/wiki/Safavid_dynasty" title="Safavid dynasty">Safavid dynasty</a> rose to power in 1501 and later conquered all of Iran.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[240]</a></sup> In South Asia, <a href="/wiki/Babur" title="Babur">Babur</a> founded the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a>. The Mughals made <a href="/wiki/Mughal_architecture" title="Mughal architecture">major contributions</a> to Islamic architecture, including the <a href="/wiki/Taj_Mahal" title="Taj Mahal">Taj Mahal</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Badshahi_mosque" title="Badshahi mosque">Badshahi mosque</a>, and compiled the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fatwa_Alamgiri" title="Fatwa Alamgiri">Fatwa Alamgiri</a>.
</p><p>The religion of the centralized states of the Gunpowder empires influenced the religious practice of their constituent populations. A <a href="/wiki/Symbiosis" title="Symbiosis">symbiosis</a> between <a href="/wiki/List_of_sultans_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="List of sultans of the Ottoman Empire">Ottoman rulers</a> and Sufism strongly influenced Islamic reign by the Ottomans from the beginning. According to Ottoman historiography, the <a href="/wiki/Legitimation" title="Legitimation">legitimation</a> of a ruler is attributed to <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Edebali" title="Sheikh Edebali">Sheikh Edebali</a> who interpreted a dream of <a href="/wiki/Osman_I" title="Osman I">Osman Gazi</a> as God's legitimation of his reign.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[241]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Mevlevi_Order" title="Mevlevi Order">Mevlevi Order</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bektashi_Order" title="Bektashi Order">Bektashi Order</a> had a close relation to the sultans,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[242]</a></sup> as Sufi-mystical as well as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Heterodox" title="Heterodox">heterodox</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Syncretic" title="Syncretic">syncretic</a> approaches to Islam flourished.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[243]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[244]</a></sup> The often forceful <a href="/wiki/Safavid_conversion_of_Iran_to_Shia_Islam" title="Safavid conversion of Iran to Shia Islam">Safavid conversion of Iran</a> to the Twelver Shia Islam of the Safavid Empire ensured the final dominance of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Twelver" title="Twelver">Twelver sect</a> within Shia Islam. Persian migrants to South Asia, as influential bureaucrats and landholders, help spread Shia Islam, forming some of the largest Shia populations outside Iran.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[245]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nader_Shah" title="Nader Shah">Nader Shah</a>, who overthrew the Safavids, attempted to improve relations with Sunnis by propagating the integration of Twelverism into Sunni Islam as a fifth <i>madhhab</i>, called Ja'farism,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[246]</a></sup> which failed to gain recognition from the Ottomans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[247]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Modern_era_.2818th_.E2.80.93_20th_centuries.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_era_(18th_â_20th_centuries)">Modern era (18th â 20th centuries)</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Portrait_Caliph_Abdulmecid_II.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1600" data-file-width="1185" decoding="async" height="297" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Portrait_Caliph_Abdulmecid_II.jpg/220px-Portrait_Caliph_Abdulmecid_II.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Portrait_Caliph_Abdulmecid_II.jpg/330px-Portrait_Caliph_Abdulmecid_II.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Portrait_Caliph_Abdulmecid_II.jpg/440px-Portrait_Caliph_Abdulmecid_II.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Portrait_Caliph_Abdulmecid_II.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abd%C3%BClmecid_II" title="AbdÃ¼lmecid II">AbdÃ¼lmecid II</a> was the last Caliph of Islam from the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_dynasty" title="Ottoman dynasty">Ottoman dynasty</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Earlier in the 14th century, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ibn_Taymiyya" title="Ibn Taymiyya">Ibn Taymiyya</a> promoted a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Puritan" title="Puritan">puritanical</a> form of Islam,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-257">[248]</a></sup> rejecting philosophical approaches in favor of simpler theology<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_257-1"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-257">[248]</a></sup> and called to open the gates of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Itjihad" title="Itjihad">itjihad</a> rather than blind imitation of scholars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito2010150_226-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito2010150-226">[218]</a></sup> He called for a jihad against those he deemed heretics<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceD_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceD-258">[249]</a></sup> but his writings only played a marginal role during his lifetime.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[250]</a></sup> During the 18thÂ century in Arabia, <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_ibn_Abd_al-Wahhab" title="Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab">Muhammad ibn 'Abd al-Wahhab</a>, influenced by the works of Ibn Taymiyya and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ibn_al-Qayyim" title="Ibn al-Qayyim">Ibn al-Qayyim</a>, founded a movement, called <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wahhabi" title="Wahhabi">Wahhabi</a> with their self-designation as <i>Muwahiddun</i>, to return to what he saw as unadultered Islam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[251]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceE_261-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceE-261">[252]</a></sup> He condemned many local Islamic customs, such as visiting the grave of Muhammad or saints, as later <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bidah" title="Bidah">innovations</a> and sinful<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceE_261-1"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceE-261">[252]</a></sup> and destroyed sacred rocks and trees, Sufi shrines, the <a href="/wiki/Destruction_of_early_Islamic_heritage_sites_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Destruction of early Islamic heritage sites in Saudi Arabia">tombs of Muhammad and his companions</a> and the tomb of Husayn at Karbala, a major Shia pilgrimage site.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito2010146_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito2010146-262">[253]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[254]</a></sup> He formed an alliance with the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Saud" title="House of Saud">Saud family</a>, which, by the 1920s, completed their conquest of the area that would become <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[255]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ma_Wanfu" title="Ma Wanfu">Ma Wanfu</a> and Ma Debao promoted salafist movements in the nineteenth century such as <a href="/wiki/Sailaifengye" title="Sailaifengye">Sailaifengye</a> in China after returning from Mecca but were eventually persecuted and forced into hiding by Sufi groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[256]</a></sup> Other groups sought to reform Sufism rather than reject it, with the <a href="/wiki/Senusiyya" title="Senusiyya">Senusiyya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ahmad" title="Muhammad Ahmad">Muhammad Ahmad</a> both waging war and establishing states in Libya and Sudan respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito2010147_266-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito2010147-266">[257]</a></sup> In India, <a href="/wiki/Shah_Waliullah_Dehlawi" title="Shah Waliullah Dehlawi">Shah Waliullah Dehlawi</a> attempted a more conciliatory style against Sufism and influenced the <a href="/wiki/Deobandi" title="Deobandi">Deobandi</a> movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito2010149_267-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito2010149-267">[258]</a></sup> In response to the Deobandi movement, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Barelwi" title="Barelwi">Barelwi</a> movement was founded as a mass movement, defending popular <a href="/wiki/Sufism" title="Sufism">Sufism</a> and reforming its practices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Canfield2002_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-Canfield2002-268">[259]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[260]</a></sup> The movement is famous for the celebration of <a href="/wiki/Mawlid" title="Mawlid">Muhammad's birthday</a> and today, is spread across the globe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[261]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Muslim_world" title="Muslim world">Muslim world</a> was generally in political decline starting the 1800s, especially regarding non-Muslim European powers. Earlier, in the fifteenth century, the <a href="/wiki/Reconquista" title="Reconquista">Reconquista</a> succeeded in ending the <a href="/wiki/Taifa" title="Taifa">Muslim presence in Iberia</a>. By the 19thÂ century; the British <a href="/wiki/Company_rule_in_India" title="Company rule in India">East India Company</a> had formally annexed the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_dynasty" title="Mughal dynasty">Mughal dynasty</a> in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELapidus2002358,_378â380,_624_271-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELapidus2002358,_378â380,_624-271">[262]</a></sup> As a response to <a href="/wiki/Imperialism" title="Imperialism">Western Imperialism</a>, many intellectuals sought to <a href="/wiki/Islamic_revival" title="Islamic revival">reform Islam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[263]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Islamic_modernism" title="Islamic modernism">Islamic modernism</a>, initially labelled by Western scholars as <a href="/wiki/Salafi_movement" title="Salafi movement"><i>Salafiyya</i></a>, embraced modern values and institutions such as democracy while being scripture-oriented.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceG_273-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceG-273">[264]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[265]</a></sup> Notable forerunners include <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Abduh" title="Muhammad Abduh">Muhammad 'Abduh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jamal_al-Din_al-Afghani" title="Jamal al-Din al-Afghani">Jamal al-Din al-Afghani</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceF_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceF-275">[266]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Abul_A%27la_Maududi" title="Abul A'la Maududi">Abul A'la Maududi</a> helped influence modern <a href="/wiki/Political_Islam" title="Political Islam">political Islam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[267]</a></sup> Similar to contemporary <a href="/wiki/Civil_code" title="Civil code">codification</a>, Shariah was for the first time partially codified into law in 1869 in the Ottoman Empire's <a href="/wiki/Mecelle" title="Mecelle">Mecelle</a> code.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[268]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Fall of the Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire disintegrated</a> after <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World WarÂ I</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Caliphate" title="Caliphate">Caliphate</a> was <a href="/wiki/Abolition_of_the_Caliphate" title="Abolition of the Caliphate">abolished in 1924</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[269]</a></sup> by the first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Turkey" title="List of Presidents of Turkey">President of the Turkish Republic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal AtatÃ¼rk">Mustafa Kemal AtatÃ¼rk</a>, as part of his <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_Reforms" title="AtatÃ¼rk's Reforms">secular reforms</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[270]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[271]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pan-Islam" title="Pan-Islam">Pan-Islamists</a> attempted to unify Muslims and competed with growing nationalist forces, such as <a href="/wiki/Pan-Arabism" title="Pan-Arabism">pan-Arabism</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">Organisation of Islamic Cooperation</a> (OIC), consisting of <a href="/wiki/Islam_by_country" title="Islam by country">Muslim-majority countries</a>, was established in 1969 after the burning of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qibli_Mosque" title="Qibli Mosque">Al-Aqsa Mosque</a> in <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[272]</a></sup>
</p><p>Contact with industrialized nations brought Muslim populations to new areas through economic migration. Many Muslims migrated as indentured servants (mostly from India and Indonesia) to the Caribbean, forming the largest Muslim populations by percentage in the Americas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHaddadSmith2002271_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHaddadSmith2002271-282">[273]</a></sup> Migration from Syria and Lebanon was the biggest contributor to the Muslim population in Latin America. The resulting urbanization and increase in trade in sub-Saharan Africa brought Muslims to settle in new areas and spread their faith, likely doubling its Muslim population between 1869 and 1914.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[274]</a></sup> Muslim immigrants began arriving largely from former colonies in several Western European nations since the 1960s, many as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guest_workers" title="Guest workers">guest workers</a>.
</p>
<h3><span id="Contemporary_era_.2820th_century.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Contemporary_era_(20th_centuryâpresent)">Contemporary era (20th centuryâpresent)</span></h3>
<p>Forerunners of Islamic modernism influenced Islamist political movements such as the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_Brotherhood" title="Muslim Brotherhood">Muslim Brotherhood</a> and related parties in the Arab world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[275]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[276]</a></sup> which performed well in elections following the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Spring" title="Arab Spring">Arab Spring</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[277]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jamaat-e-Islami" title="Jamaat-e-Islami">Jamaat-e-Islami</a> in South Asia and the <a href="/wiki/Justice_and_Development_Party_(Turkey)" title="Justice and Development Party (Turkey)">AK Party</a>, which has democratically been in power in Turkey for decades. In <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Revolution" title="Iranian Revolution">revolution</a> replaced a <a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">secular</a> monarchy with an <a href="/wiki/Islamic_state" title="Islamic state">Islamic state</a>. Others such as <a href="/wiki/Rashid_Rida" title="Rashid Rida">Sayyid Rashid Rida</a> broke away from Islamic modernists<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[278]</a></sup> and pushed against embracing what he saw as Western influence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[279]</a></sup> While some were <a href="/wiki/Political_quietism_in_Islam" title="Political quietism in Islam">quietist</a>, others believed in violence against those opposing them even other Muslims, such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_State_of_Iraq_and_the_Levant" title="Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant">Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant</a>, who would even attempt to recreate the <a href="/wiki/Modern_gold_dinar" title="Modern gold dinar">modern gold dinar</a> as their monetary system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[280]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ulu_mosque,_Utrecht_26.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4608" data-file-width="3456" decoding="async" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Ulu_mosque%2C_Utrecht_26.jpg/220px-Ulu_mosque%2C_Utrecht_26.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Ulu_mosque%2C_Utrecht_26.jpg/330px-Ulu_mosque%2C_Utrecht_26.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Ulu_mosque%2C_Utrecht_26.jpg/440px-Ulu_mosque%2C_Utrecht_26.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ulu_mosque,_Utrecht_26.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ulu mosque in <a href="/wiki/Utrecht" title="Utrecht">Utrecht</a>, Netherlands</div></div></div>
<p>In opposition to Islamic political movements, in 20th century Turkey, the military carried out <a href="/wiki/1997_Turkish_military_memorandum" title="1997 Turkish military memorandum">coups</a> to oust Islamist governments, and headscarves were legally restricted, as also happened in Tunisia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[281]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[282]</a></sup> In other places religious power was co-opted, such as in Saudi Arabia, where the state monopolized religious scholarship and are often seen as puppets of the state<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-economist_292-0"><a href="#cite_note-economist-292">[283]</a></sup> while Egypt nationalized <a href="/wiki/Al-Azhar_University" title="Al-Azhar University">Al-Azhar University</a>, previously an independent voice checking state power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[284]</a></sup> Salafism was funded for its quietism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[285]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia campaigned against revolutionary Islamist movements in the Middle East, in opposition to Iran,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-20160105-maps_295-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-20160105-maps-295">[286]</a></sup> Turkey<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[287]</a></sup> and Qatar.
</p><p>Muslim minorities of various ethnicities have been persecuted as a religious group.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[288]</a></sup> This has been undertaken by communist forces like the <a href="/wiki/Khmer_Rouge" title="Khmer Rouge">Khmer Rouge</a>, who viewed them as their primary enemy to be exterminated since they stood out and worshiped their own god<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[289]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Chinese Communist Party">Chinese Communist Party</a> in <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang_internment_camps" title="Xinjiang internment camps">Xinjiang</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Beydoun2018_299-0"><a href="#cite_note-Beydoun2018-299">[290]</a></sup> and by nationalist forces such as during the <a href="/wiki/Bosnian_genocide" title="Bosnian genocide">Bosnian genocide</a>.
</p><p>The globalization of communication has increased dissemination of religious information. The adoption of the <a href="/wiki/Hijab" title="Hijab">hijab</a> has grown more common<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[291]</a></sup> and some Muslim intellectuals are increasingly striving to separate scriptural Islamic beliefs from cultural traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENigosian200441_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENigosian200441-301">[292]</a></sup> Among other groups, this access to information has led to the rise of popular "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Televangelist" title="Televangelist">televangelist</a>" preachers, such as <a href="/wiki/Amr_Khaled" title="Amr Khaled">Amr Khaled</a>, who compete with the traditional <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ulema" title="Ulema">ulema</a> in their reach and have decentralized religious authority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[293]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito2010263_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito2010263-303">[294]</a></sup> More "individualized" interpretations of Islam<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[295]</a></sup> notably include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liberal_Muslims" title="Liberal Muslims">Liberal Muslims</a> who attempt to reconcile religious traditions with current secular governance<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito2004118â119,_179_305-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito2004118â119,_179-305">[296]</a></sup> and women's issues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERippin2001288_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERippin2001288-306">[297]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MuslimWorldDemographics2022.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1314" data-file-width="2560" decoding="async" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/MuslimWorldDemographics2022.png/220px-MuslimWorldDemographics2022.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/MuslimWorldDemographics2022.png/330px-MuslimWorldDemographics2022.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/MuslimWorldDemographics2022.png/440px-MuslimWorldDemographics2022.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MuslimWorldDemographics2022.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Muslim distribution worldwide, based on latest available data<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[298]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Muslim_world" title="Muslim world">Muslim world</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ummah" title="Ummah">Ummah</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Islam_by_country" title="Islam by country">Islam by country</a> and <a href="/wiki/Muslim_population_growth" title="Muslim population growth">Muslim population growth</a></div>
<p>A 2020 demographic study reported that 24.1% of the global population, or 1-1.8 billion people, are Muslims.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pewresearch.org_5-2"><a href="#cite_note-pewresearch.org-5">[5]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto2_308-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-308">[299]</a></sup> In 1900, this estimate was 12.3%,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[300]</a></sup> in 1990 it was 19.9%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_39-1"><a href="#cite_note-:3-39">[38]</a></sup> and projections suggest the proportion will be 29.7% by 2050.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pew2015_310-0"><a href="#cite_note-pew2015-310">[301]</a></sup> It has been estimated that 87â90% of Muslims are Sunni and 10â13% are Shia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPew_Forum_for_Religion_&amp;_Public_Life20091_33-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPew_Forum_for_Religion_&amp;_Public_Life20091-33">[32]</a></sup> with a minority belonging to other sects. Approximately 49 countries are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Muslim_majority_countries" title="List of Muslim majority countries">Muslim-majority</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPew_Forum_for_Religion_&amp;_Public_Life200911_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPew_Forum_for_Religion_&amp;_Public_Life200911-311">[302]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[303]</a></sup> with 62% of the world's Muslims living in Asia, and 683 million adherents in <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Indonesia" title="Islam in Indonesia">Indonesia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Pakistan" title="Islam in Pakistan">Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_India" title="Islam in India">India</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Bangladesh" title="Islam in Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a> alone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USN&amp;WR_313-0"><a href="#cite_note-USN&amp;WR-313">[304]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPew_Forum_for_Religion_&amp;_Public_Life200915,_17_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPew_Forum_for_Religion_&amp;_Public_Life200915,_17-314">[305]</a></sup> Most estimates indicate <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_China" title="Islam in China">China</a> has approximately 20 to 30 million Muslims (1.5% to 2% of the population).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[306]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[307]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Europe" title="Islam in Europe">Islam in Europe</a> is the second largest religion after <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> in many countries, with growth rates due primarily to immigration and higher birth rates of Muslims in 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[308]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Religious_conversion" title="Religious conversion">Religious conversion</a> has no net impact on the Muslim population growth as "the number of people who <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Convert_to_Islam" title="Convert to Islam">become Muslims through conversion</a> seems to be roughly equal to the number of Muslims who leave the faith".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Future_of_the_Global_Muslim_Population_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_Future_of_the_Global_Muslim_Population-318">[309]</a></sup> It is estimated that, by 2050, the number of Muslims will nearly equal the number of Christians around the world, "due to the young age and high <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fertility_rate" title="Fertility rate">fertility-rate</a> of Muslims relative to other religious groups".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pew2015_310-1"><a href="#cite_note-pew2015-310">[301]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Schools_and_branches">Schools and branches</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Islamic_schools_and_branches" title="Islamic schools and branches">Islamic schools and branches</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Shia%E2%80%93Sunni_relations" title="ShiaâSunni relations">ShiaâSunni relations</a></div>
