<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni Islam</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sahih_Al-Bukhari_in_English.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="835" data-file-width="908" decoding="async" height="202" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Sahih_Al-Bukhari_in_English.png/220px-Sahih_Al-Bukhari_in_English.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Sahih_Al-Bukhari_in_English.png/330px-Sahih_Al-Bukhari_in_English.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Sahih_Al-Bukhari_in_English.png/440px-Sahih_Al-Bukhari_in_English.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sahih_Al-Bukhari_in_English.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The nine volumes of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sahih_Al-Bukhari" title="Sahih Al-Bukhari">Sahih Al-Bukhari</a>, one of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Al-Kutub_Al-Sittah" title="Al-Kutub Al-Sittah">six Sunni hadith books</a></div></div></div>
<p>Sunni Islam or Sunnism is the name for the largest denomination in Islam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[310]</a></sup> The term is a contraction of the phrase "ahl as-sunna wa'l-jamaat", which means "people of the <a href="/wiki/Sunnah" title="Sunnah">sunna</a> (the traditions of the prophet Muhammad) and the community".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[311]</a></sup> Sunnis, or sometimes Sunnites, believe that the first four caliphs were the rightful successors to Muhammad and primarily reference <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Al-Kutub_Al-Sittah" title="Al-Kutub Al-Sittah">six major hadith works</a> for legal matters, while following one of the four traditional schools of jurisprudence: Hanafi, Hanbali, Maliki or Shafi'i.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:15_23-1"><a href="#cite_note-:15-23">[22]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[312]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sunni schools of theology encompass Asharism founded by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Al-Ash%CA%BFar%C4%AB" title="Al-AshÊ¿arÄ«">Al-AshÊ¿arÄ«</a> (c. 874â936), Maturidi by <a href="/wiki/Abu_Mansur_al-Maturidi" title="Abu Mansur al-Maturidi">Abu Mansur al-Maturidi</a> (853â944 CE) and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Traditionalist_theology_(Islam)" title="Traditionalist theology (Islam)">traditionalist theology</a> under the leadership of Ahmad ibn Hanbal (780â855 CE). Traditionalist theology is characterized by its adherence to a literal understanding of the Quran and the Sunnah, the belief in the Quran is uncreated and eternal, and opposition to reason (kalam) in religious and ethical matters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[313]</a></sup> On the other hand, Maturidism asserts, scripture is not needed for basic ethics and that <i>good</i> and <i>evil</i> can be understood by reason alone,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[314]</a></sup> but people rely on revelation, for matters beyond human's comprehension. Asharism holds that ethics can derive just from divine revelation but not from human reason. However, Asharism accepts reason regarding exegetical matters and combines MuÊ¿tazila approaches with traditionalist ideas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito1999280_324-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito1999280-324">[315]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 18thÂ century, Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab led a Salafi movement, referred by outsiders as Wahhabism, in modern-day Saudi Arabia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[316]</a></sup> A similar movement called <a href="/wiki/Ahl_al-Hadith" title="Ahl al-Hadith">Ahl al-Hadith</a> also de-emphasized the centuries' old Sunni legal tradition, preferring to directly follow the Quran and Hadith. The <i><a href="/wiki/Nur_movement" title="Nur movement">Nurcu</a></i> Sunni movement was by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Said_Nursi" title="Said Nursi">Said Nursi</a> (1877â1960);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Svante_E._Cornell_p._283_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-Svante_E._Cornell_p._283-326">[317]</a></sup> it incorporates elements of Sufism and science,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Svante_E._Cornell_p._283_326-1"><a href="#cite_note-Svante_E._Cornell_p._283-326">[317]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[318]</a></sup> and has given rise to the <a href="/wiki/G%C3%BClen_movement" title="GÃ¼len movement">GÃ¼len movement</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Shia">Shia</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shia Islam</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kerbela_Hussein_Moschee.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1632" data-file-width="2464" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Kerbela_Hussein_Moschee.jpg/220px-Kerbela_Hussein_Moschee.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Kerbela_Hussein_Moschee.jpg/330px-Kerbela_Hussein_Moschee.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Kerbela_Hussein_Moschee.jpg/440px-Kerbela_Hussein_Moschee.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kerbela_Hussein_Moschee.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Imam_Husayn_Shrine" title="Imam Husayn Shrine">Imam Hussein Shrine</a> in <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a> is a holy site for Shia Muslims</div></div></div>
<p>Shia Islam, or Shi'ism, is the second-largest Muslim denomination. Shias, or Shiites, split with Sunnis over Muhammad's <a href="/wiki/Succession_to_Muhammad" title="Succession to Muhammad">successor</a> as leader, who the Shia believed must be from certain descendants of Muhammad's family known as the <a href="/wiki/Ahl_al-Bayt" title="Ahl al-Bayt">Ahl al-Bayt</a> and those leaders, referred to as <a href="/wiki/Imamate_in_Shia_doctrine" title="Imamate in Shia doctrine">Imams</a>, have additional spiritual authority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[319]</a></sup> Some of the first Imams are revered by all Shia groups and Sunnis, such as <a href="/wiki/Ali" title="Ali">Ali</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zaidism" title="Zaidism">Zaidi</a>, the oldest branch, reject special powers of Imams and are sometimes considered a 'fifth school' of Sunni Islam rather than a Shia sect.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[320]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Arab-IsraeliConflict_330-0"><a href="#cite_note-Arab-IsraeliConflict-330">[321]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IraqEffect_331-0"><a href="#cite_note-IraqEffect-331">[322]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Twelvers" title="Twelvers">Twelvers</a>, the largest Shia branch, believe in <a href="/wiki/Twelve_Imams" title="Twelve Imams">twelve Imams</a>, the last of whom went into <a href="/wiki/Occultation_(Islam)" title="Occultation (Islam)">occultation</a> to return one day. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ismailism" title="Ismailism">Ismailis</a> split with the Twelvers over who was the seventh Imam and have split into more groups over the status of successive Imams, with the largest group being the <a href="/wiki/Nizari_Isma%27ilism" title="Nizari Isma'ilism">Nizaris</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Newman2013_332-0"><a href="#cite_note-Newman2013-332">[323]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ibadi">Ibadi</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ibadi_Islam" title="Ibadi Islam">Ibadi Islam</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Ibadi_Islam" title="Ibadi Islam">Ibadi Islam</a> or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ibadism" title="Ibadism">Ibadism</a> is practised by 1.45Â million Muslims around the world (~ 0.08% of all Muslims), most of them in <a href="/wiki/Oman" title="Oman">Oman</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[324]</a></sup> Ibadism is often associated with and viewed as a moderate variation of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khawarij" title="Khawarij">Khawarij</a> movement, though Ibadis themselves object to this classification. Unlike most Kharijite groups, Ibadism does not regard sinful Muslims as unbelievers. Ibadi hadiths, such as the <a href="/wiki/Jami_Sahih" title="Jami Sahih">Jami Sahih</a> collection, uses chains of narrators from early Islamic history they considered trustworthy but most Ibadi hadiths are also found in standard Sunni collections and contemporary Ibadis often approve of the standard Sunni collections.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[325]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="center"><div class="floatnone"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Islam_branches_and_schools..png" title="An overview of the major sects and madhahib of Islam"><img alt="An overview of the major sects and madhahib of Islam" data-file-height="448" data-file-width="698" decoding="async" height="448" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/80/Islam_branches_and_schools..png" width="698"/></a></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Quranism">Quranism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Quranism" title="Quranism">Quranism</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Quranism" title="Quranism">Quranists</a> are Muslims who generally believe that Islamic law and guidance should only be based on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qur%27an" title="Qur'an">Qur'an</a>, rejecting the <a href="/wiki/Sunnah" title="Sunnah">Sunnah</a>, thus partially or completely doubting the <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_hadith" title="Criticism of hadith">religious authority, reliability or authenticity</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Hadith" title="Hadith">Hadith</a> literature, which they claim are fabricated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Quranists_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_Quranists-335">[326]</a></sup>
</p><p>There were first critics of the hadith traditions as early as the time of the scholar <a href="/wiki/Al-Shafi%27i" title="Al-Shafi'i">Al-Shafi'i</a>; however, their arguments did not find much favor among Muslims. From the 19th century onwards, reformist thinkers like <a href="/wiki/Syed_Ahmad_Khan" title="Syed Ahmad Khan">Sayyid Ahmad Khan</a>, Abdullah Chakralawi, and later <a href="/wiki/Ghulam_Ahmed_Perwez" title="Ghulam Ahmed Perwez">Ghulam Ahmad Parwez</a> in India began to systematically question the hadith and the Islamic tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[327]</a></sup> At the same time, there was a long-standing discussion on the sole authority of the Quran in Egypt, initiated by an article by <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Tawfiq_Sidqi" title="Muhammad Tawfiq Sidqi">Muhammad Tawfiq Sidqi</a> named "Islam is the Quran alone" (<i>al-IslÄm huwa l-QurÊ¾Än waá¸¥da-hÅ«)</i>  in the magazine al-ManÄr.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[328]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[329]</a></sup> Quranism also took on a political dimension in the 20th century when <a href="/wiki/Muammar_Gaddafi" title="Muammar Gaddafi">Muammar al-Gaddafi</a> declared the Quran to be the constitution of Libya.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[330]</a></sup> In America, <a href="/wiki/Rashad_Khalifa" title="Rashad Khalifa">Rashad Khalifa</a>, an Egyptian-American biochemist and discoverer of the <a href="/wiki/Quran_code" title="Quran code">Quran code</a> (Code 19), which is a hypothetical mathematical code in the Quran, founded the organization "United Submitters International".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[331]</a></sup>
</p><p>The rejection of the hadith leads in some cases to differences in the way religion is practiced for example in the ritual prayer. While some Quranists traditionally pray five times a day, others reduce the number to three or even two daily prayers. There are also different views on the details of prayer or other pillars of Islam such as zakÄt, fasting, or the Hajj.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[332]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_denominations">Other denominations</span></h3>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Alevism" title="Alevism">Bektashi Alevism</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Syncretism" title="Syncretism">syncretic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Heterodoxy" title="Heterodoxy">heterodox</a> local Islamic tradition, whose adherents follow the mystical (<a href="/wiki/Batin_(Islam)" title="Batin (Islam)">bÄá¹­enÄ«</a>) teachings of Ali and <a href="/wiki/Haji_Bektash_Veli" title="Haji Bektash Veli">Haji Bektash Veli</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[333]</a></sup> Alevism incorporates Turkish beliefs present during the 14thÂ century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_343-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-343">[334]</a></sup> such as <a href="/wiki/Tengrism" title="Tengrism">Shamanism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Animism" title="Animism">Animism</a>, mixed with Shias and Sufi beliefs, adopted by some Turkish tribes. It has been estimated that there are 10Â million to over 20Â million (~0.5%â1% of all Muslims) Alevis worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[335]</a></sup></li>
<li>The <a href="/wiki/Ahmadiyya" title="Ahmadiyya">Ahmadiyya</a> movement was founded by <a href="/wiki/Mirza_Ghulam_Ahmad" title="Mirza Ghulam Ahmad">Mirza Ghulam Ahmad</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[336]</a></sup> in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> in 1889.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ahmadi_346-0"><a href="#cite_note-ahmadi-346">[337]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[e]</a></sup> Ahmad claimed to be the "Promised Messiah" or "Imam Mahdi" of prophecy. Today the group has 10 to 20 million practitioners, but is rejected by most Muslims as heretical,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito2004[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidE324pQEEQQcCpgPA11_11]_348-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito2004[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidE324pQEEQQcCpgPA11_11]-348">[338]</a></sup> and Ahmadis have been subject to religious persecution and discrimination since the movement's inception.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[339]</a></sup></li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Non-denominational_Muslims">Non-denominational Muslims</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Non-denominational_Muslim" title="Non-denominational Muslim">Non-denominational Muslim</a></div>
<p>Non-denominational Muslims is an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Umbrella_term" title="Umbrella term">umbrella term</a> that has been used for and by Muslims who do not belong to or do not self-identify with a specific <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_denomination" title="Islamic denomination">Islamic denomination</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[340]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kirkham_351-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kirkham-351">[341]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pollack_352-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pollack-352">[342]</a></sup> Recent surveys report that large proportions of Muslims in some parts of the world self-identify as "just Muslim", although there is little published analysis available regarding the motivations underlying this response.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[343]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[344]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[345]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew Research Center</a> reports that respondents self-identifying as "just Muslim" make up a majority of Muslims in seven countries (and a plurality in three others), with the highest proportion in <a href="/wiki/Kazakhstan" title="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a> at 74%. At least one in five Muslims in at least 22 countries self-identify in this way.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pew_356-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pew-356">[346]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mysticism">Mysticism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sufism" title="Sufism">Sufism</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Sufi%E2%80%93Salafi_relations" title="SufiâSalafi relations">SufiâSalafi relations</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mevlana_Konya.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="375" data-file-width="500" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Mevlana_Konya.jpg/220px-Mevlana_Konya.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Mevlana_Konya.jpg/330px-Mevlana_Konya.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Mevlana_Konya.jpg/440px-Mevlana_Konya.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mevlana_Konya.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Whirling Dervishes, or <a href="/wiki/Mevlevi_Order" title="Mevlevi Order">Mevlevi Order</a> by the tomb of Sufi-mystic <a href="/wiki/Rumi" title="Rumi">Rumi</a></div></div></div>
<p>Sufism (Arabic: <span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">ØªØµÙÙ</span></span>, <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">tasawwuf</i></span>), is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mystical" title="Mystical">mystical</a>-<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ascetic" title="Ascetic">ascetic</a> approach to Islam that seeks to find a direct <a href="/wiki/Divine_presence" title="Divine presence">personal experience of God</a>. Classical Sufi scholars defined <i>Tasawwuf</i> as "a science whose objective is the reparation of the heart and turning it away from all else but God", through "intuitive and emotional faculties" that one must be trained to use.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[347]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[348]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[349]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[350]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[351]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ahmed_Zarruq_2008_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ahmed_Zarruq_2008-362">[352]</a></sup> It is not a sect of Islam and its adherents belong to the various Muslim denominations. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ismaili" title="Ismaili">Ismaili</a> Shias, whose teachings root in <a href="/wiki/Gnosticism" title="Gnosticism">Gnosticism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neoplatonism" title="Neoplatonism">Neoplatonism</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[353]</a></sup> as well as by the <a href="/wiki/Illuminationism" title="Illuminationism">Illuminationist</a> and <a href="/wiki/School_of_Isfahan" title="School of Isfahan">Isfahan</a> schools of Islamic philosophy have developed mystical interpretations of Islam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[354]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hasan_al-Basri" title="Hasan al-Basri">Hasan al-Basri</a>, the early Sufi ascetic often portrayed as one of the earliest Sufis,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[355]</a></sup> emphasized fear of failing God's expectations of obedience. In contrast, later prominent Sufis, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mansur_Al-Hallaj" title="Mansur Al-Hallaj">Mansur Al-Hallaj</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rumi" title="Rumi">Jalaluddin Rumi</a>, emphasized religiosity based on love towards God. Such devotion would also have an impact on the arts, with Rumi, still one of the best selling poets in America,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[356]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[357]</a></sup> writing his Persian poem <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Masnawi" title="Masnawi">Masnawi</a> and the works of <a href="/wiki/Hafez" title="Hafez">Hafez</a> (1315â1390) are often considered the pinnacle of Persian poetry.
</p><p>Sufis reject <i>materialism</i> and <i>ego</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[358]</a></sup> and regard everything as if it was sent by god alone, Sufi strongly believes in the oneness of god.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[359]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sufis see <i>tasawwuf</i> as an inseparable part of Islam, just like the <i>sharia</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChittick20083â4,_11_370-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChittick20083â4,_11-370">[360]</a></sup> Traditional Sufis, such as <a href="/wiki/Bayazid_Bastami" title="Bayazid Bastami">Bayazid Bastami</a>, Jalaluddin Rumi, <a href="/wiki/Haji_Bektash_Veli" title="Haji Bektash Veli">Haji Bektash Veli</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Junaid_Baghdadi" title="Junaid Baghdadi">Junaid Baghdadi</a>, and Al-Ghazali, argued for Sufism as being based upon the tenets of Islam and the teachings of the prophet.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[361]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChittick20083â4,_11_370-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChittick20083â4,_11-370">[360]</a></sup> Historian <a href="/wiki/Nile_Green" title="Nile Green">Nile Green</a> argued that Islam in the Medieval period, was more or less <i>Sufism</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Peacock_240-1"><a href="#cite_note-Peacock-240">[232]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 77">(p77)</span></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 24">(p24)</span></sup> Popular devotional practices such as the veneration of Sufi saints have been viewed as innovations from the original religion from followers of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salafism" title="Salafism">salafism</a>, who have sometimes physically attacked Sufis, leading to a deterioration in <a href="/wiki/Sufi%E2%80%93Salafi_relations" title="SufiâSalafi relations">SufiâSalafi relations</a>.
</p><p>Sufi congregations form orders (<i><a href="/wiki/Tariqa" title="Tariqa">tariqa</a></i>) centered around a teacher (<i><a href="/wiki/Wali" title="Wali">wali</a></i>) who traces a spiritual chain back to Muhammad.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[362]</a></sup> Sufis played an important role in the formation of Muslim societies through their missionary and educational activities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB-Sufism_198-1"><a href="#cite_note-EB-Sufism-198">[191]</a></sup> Sufi influenced Ahle Sunnat movement or <a href="/wiki/Barelvi" title="Barelvi">Barelvi</a> movement defends Sufi practices and beliefs with over 200 million followers in south Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[363]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[364]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[365]</a></sup> Sufism is prominent in Central Asia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[366]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[367]</a></sup> as well as in African countries like <a href="/wiki/Tunisia" title="Tunisia">Tunisia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Algeria" title="Algeria">Algeria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Senegal" title="Senegal">Senegal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chad" title="Chad">Chad</a> and <a href="/wiki/Niger" title="Niger">Niger</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pew_356-1"><a href="#cite_note-Pew-356">[346]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[368]</a></sup>
</p>

<li><a href="/wiki/Istijarah" title="Istijarah"><i>Istijarah</i> <span style="font-size:85%;">(asylum)</span></a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Prisoners_of_war_in_Islam" title="Prisoners of war in Islam">Prisoners of war</a></li></ul></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-below" style="border-top:1px solid #dcf5dc;border-bottom:1px solid #dcf5dc;padding-bottom:0.4em;">
<a href="/wiki/Islamic_studies" title="Islamic studies">Islamic studies</a></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Fiqh" title="Template:Fiqh"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Fiqh" title="Template talk:Fiqh"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Fiqh&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Sharia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fiqh" title="Fiqh">Fiqh</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Logic_in_Islamic_philosophy#Islamic_law_and_theology" title="Logic in Islamic philosophy">Logic in Islamic philosophy Â§Â Islamic law and theology</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Sharia</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Religious_law" title="Religious law">religious law</a> forming part of the Islamic tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:15_23-2"><a href="#cite_note-:15-23">[22]</a></sup> It is derived from the religious precepts of Islam, particularly the Quran and the Hadith. In Arabic, the term sharÄ«Ê¿ah refers to God's divine law and is contrasted with <i><a href="/wiki/Fiqh" title="Fiqh">fiqh</a></i>, which refers to its scholarly interpretations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ODI_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-ODI-379">[369]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vikor_380-0"><a href="#cite_note-vikor-380">[370]</a></sup> The manner of its application in modern times has been a subject of dispute between Muslim traditionalists and reformists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:15_23-3"><a href="#cite_note-:15-23">[22]</a></sup>
</p><p>Traditional <a href="/wiki/Principles_of_Islamic_jurisprudence" title="Principles of Islamic jurisprudence">theory of Islamic jurisprudence</a> recognizes four <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sources_of_sharia" title="Sources of sharia">sources of sharia</a>: the Quran, sunnah (<i>Hadith</i> and <a href="/wiki/Prophetic_biography" title="Prophetic biography"><i>Sira</i></a>), <a href="/wiki/Qiyas" title="Qiyas">qiyas</a> (analogical reasoning), and <i><a href="/wiki/Ijma" title="Ijma">ijma</a></i> (juridical consensus).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Esposito,_John_2001_381-0"><a href="#cite_note-Esposito,_John_2001-381">[371]</a></sup> Different <a href="/wiki/Madhhab" title="Madhhab">legal schools</a> developed methodologies for deriving sharia rulings from scriptural sources using a process known as <i><a href="/wiki/Ijtihad" title="Ijtihad">ijtihad</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ODI_379-1"><a href="#cite_note-ODI-379">[369]</a></sup> Traditional jurisprudence distinguishes two principal branches of law,<i><a href="/wiki/Ibadah" title="Ibadah">Ê¿ibÄdÄt</a></i> (rituals) and <i><a href="/wiki/Muamalat" title="Muamalat">muÊ¿ÄmalÄt</a></i> (social relations), which together comprise a wide range of topics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ODI_379-2"><a href="#cite_note-ODI-379">[369]</a></sup> Its rulings assign actions to one of five categories called <a href="/wiki/Ahkam" title="Ahkam">ahkam</a>: mandatory (<i><a href="/wiki/Fard" title="Fard">fard</a></i>), recommended (<i><a href="/wiki/Mustahabb" title="Mustahabb">mustahabb</a></i>), permitted (<i><a href="/wiki/Mubah" title="Mubah">mubah</a></i>), abhorred (<i><a href="/wiki/Makruh" title="Makruh">makruh</a></i>), and prohibited (<i><a href="/wiki/Haram" title="Haram">haram</a></i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ODI_379-3"><a href="#cite_note-ODI-379">[369]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vikor_380-1"><a href="#cite_note-vikor-380">[370]</a></sup> Forgiveness is much celebrated in Islam<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELeaman2006[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidisDgI0-0Ip4CpgPA214_214]_382-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELeaman2006[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidisDgI0-0Ip4CpgPA214_214]-382">[372]</a></sup> and, in criminal law, while imposing a penalty on an offender in proportion to their offense is considered permissible; forgiving the offender is better. To go one step further by offering a favor to the offender is regarded as the peak of excellence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENigosian2004[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidmy7hnALd_NkCpgPA116_116]_383-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENigosian2004[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidmy7hnALd_NkCpgPA116_116]-383">[373]</a></sup> Some areas of sharia overlap with the Western notion of law while others correspond more broadly to living life in accordance with God's will.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vikor_380-2"><a href="#cite_note-vikor-380">[370]</a></sup>
</p><p>Historically, sharia was interpreted by independent jurists (<a href="/wiki/Mufti" title="Mufti">muftis</a>). Their legal opinions (<a href="/wiki/Fatwa" title="Fatwa">fatwa</a>) were taken into account by ruler-appointed <a href="/wiki/Qadi" title="Qadi">judges</a> who presided over <a href="/wiki/Qadi" title="Qadi">qÄá¸Ä«</a>'s courts, and by <i><a href="/wiki/Mazalim" title="Mazalim">maáºÄlim</a></i> courts, which were controlled by the ruler's council and administered criminal law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ODI_379-4"><a href="#cite_note-ODI-379">[369]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vikor_380-3"><a href="#cite_note-vikor-380">[370]</a></sup> In the modern era, sharia-based criminal laws were widely replaced by statutes inspired by European models.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vikor_380-4"><a href="#cite_note-vikor-380">[370]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>'s 19th-century <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">Tanzimat</a> reforms lead to the <a href="/wiki/Mecelle" title="Mecelle">Mecelle</a> civil code and represented the first attempt to <a href="/wiki/Codification_(law)" title="Codification (law)">codify</a> sharia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[374]</a></sup> While the constitutions of most Muslim-majority states contain references to sharia, its classical rules were largely retained only in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Status_(law)" title="Status (law)">personal status</a> (family) laws.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vikor_380-5"><a href="#cite_note-vikor-380">[370]</a></sup> Legislative bodies which codified these laws sought to modernize them without abandoning their foundations in traditional jurisprudence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vikor_380-6"><a href="#cite_note-vikor-380">[370]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mayer_385-0"><a href="#cite_note-mayer-385">[375]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Islamic_revival" title="Islamic revival">Islamic revival</a> of the late 20thÂ century brought along calls by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamist" title="Islamist">Islamist</a> movements for complete implementation of sharia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vikor_380-7"><a href="#cite_note-vikor-380">[370]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mayer_385-1"><a href="#cite_note-mayer-385">[375]</a></sup> The role of sharia has become a contested topic around the world. There are ongoing debates whether sharia is compatible with secular forms of government, human rights, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_thought" title="Freedom of thought">freedom of thought</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_rights" title="Women's rights">women's rights</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-naim96_386-0"><a href="#cite_note-naim96-386">[376]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hajjar2004_387-0"><a href="#cite_note-hajjar2004-387">[377]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Schools_of_jurisprudence">Schools of jurisprudence</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Madhhab_Map3.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3882" data-file-width="8000" decoding="async" height="107" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Madhhab_Map3.png/220px-Madhhab_Map3.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Madhhab_Map3.png/330px-Madhhab_Map3.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Madhhab_Map3.png/440px-Madhhab_Map3.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Madhhab_Map3.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Islamic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Madh%27hab" title="Madh'hab">schools of law</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_world" title="Muslim world">Muslim world</a></div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Madhhab" title="Madhhab">Madhhab</a></div>
<p>A school of jurisprudence is referred to as a <i>madhhab</i> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">ÙØ°ÙØ¨</span>). The four major Sunni schools are the <a href="/wiki/Hanafi" title="Hanafi">Hanafi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maliki" title="Maliki">Maliki</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shafi%27i" title="Shafi'i">Shafi'i</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hanbali" title="Hanbali">Hanbali</a> madhahs while the three major Shia schools are the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ja%27fari" title="Ja'fari">Ja'fari</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zaidiyyah" title="Zaidiyyah">Zaidi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Isma%27ilism" title="Isma'ilism">Isma'ili</a> madhahib. Each differs in their methodology, called <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Usul_al-fiqh" title="Usul al-fiqh">Usul al-fiqh</a></i> ("principles of jurisprudence"). The following of decisions by a religious expert without necessarily examining the decision's reasoning is called <i><a href="/wiki/Taqlid" title="Taqlid">taqlid</a></i>. The term <i><a href="/wiki/Salafi_movement" title="Salafi movement">ghair muqallid</a></i> literally refers to those who do not use taqlid and, by extension, do not have a madhab.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[378]</a></sup> The practice of an individual interpreting law with independent reasoning is called <i>ijtihad</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWeiss20023,_161_389-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWeiss20023,_161-389">[379]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Society">Society</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religious_personages">Religious personages</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ulama" title="Ulama">Ulama</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%BE_%D0%91%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8._%D0%A2%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%88%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%B4%D0%BB%D1%8F_%D0%B4%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B9_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3939" data-file-width="5897" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%BE_%D0%91%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8._%D0%A2%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%88%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%B4%D0%BB%D1%8F_%D0%B4%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B9_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%BE_%D0%91%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8._%D0%A2%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%88%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%B4%D0%BB%D1%8F_%D0%B4%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B9_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%BE_%D0%91%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8._%D0%A2%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%88%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%B4%D0%BB%D1%8F_%D0%B4%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B9_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%BE_%D0%91%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8._%D0%A2%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%88%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%B4%D0%BB%D1%8F_%D0%B4%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B9_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%BE_%D0%91%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8._%D0%A2%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%88%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%B4%D0%BB%D1%8F_%D0%B4%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B9_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%BE_%D0%91%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8._%D0%A2%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%88%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%B4%D0%BB%D1%8F_%D0%B4%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B9_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%BE_%D0%91%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8._%D0%A2%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%88%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%B4%D0%BB%D1%8F_%D0%B4%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B9_(cropped).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Crimean_Tatars" title="Crimean Tatars">Crimean Tatar</a> Muslim students (1856)</div></div></div>
<p>Islam, like Judaism, has no clergy in the <a href="/wiki/Sacerdotalism" title="Sacerdotalism">sacerdotal</a> sense, such as priests who mediate between God and people. <i><a href="/wiki/Imam" title="Imam">Imam</a></i> (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø¥ÙØ§Ù</span></span>) is the religious title used to refer to an Islamic leadership position, often in the context of conducting an Islamic worship service.
</p><p>Religious interpretation is presided over by the <i>âulama</i> (Arabic: Ø¹ÙÙØ§Ø¡), a term used describe the body of Muslim scholars who have received training in <a href="/wiki/Islamic_studies" title="Islamic studies">Islamic studies</a>. A scholar of the hadith is called a <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muhaddith" title="Muhaddith">muhaddith</a></i>, a scholar of jurisprudence is called a <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Faqih" title="Faqih">faqih</a></i> (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">ÙÙÙÙ</span></span>), a jurist who is qualified to issue legal opinions or <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fatwas" title="Fatwas">fatwas</a></i> is called a <a href="/wiki/Mufti" title="Mufti">mufti</a>, and a <i><a href="/wiki/Qadi" title="Qadi">qadi</a></i> is an Islamic judge. <a href="/wiki/Honorific" title="Honorific">Honorific</a> titles given to scholars include <a href="/wiki/Sheikh" title="Sheikh">sheikh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mullah" title="Mullah">mullah</a> and <i><a href="/wiki/Mawlawi_(Islamic_title)" title="Mawlawi (Islamic title)">mawlawi</a></i>.
</p><p>Some Muslims also venerate <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saints_in_Islam" title="Saints in Islam">saints</a> associated with <a href="/wiki/Islamic_view_of_miracles" title="Islamic view of miracles">miracles</a> (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">ÙØ±Ø§ÙØ§Øª</span></span>, <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">karÄmÄt</i></span>). The practice of visiting the tombs of prophets and saints is known as <i><a href="/wiki/Ziyarat" title="Ziyarat">ziyarat</a></i>. Unlike saints in Christianity, Muslim saints are usually acknowledged informally by the consensus of common people, not by scholars.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Governance">Governance</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Political_aspects_of_Islam" title="Political aspects of Islam">Political aspects of Islam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islamic_economics" title="Islamic economics">Islamic economics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islamic_military_jurisprudence" title="Islamic military jurisprudence">Islamic military jurisprudence</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jihad" title="Jihad">Jihad</a></div>
<p>Mainstream Islamic law does not distinguish between "matters of church" and "matters of state"; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ulema" title="Ulema">scholars</a> function as both jurists and theologians. Various forms of Islamic jurisprudence therefore rule on matters than in other societal context might be considered the preserve of the state. Terms traditionally used to refer to Muslim leaders include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caliph" title="Caliph">Caliph</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sultan" title="Sultan">Sultan</a>, and terms associated with traditionally Muslim states include <a href="/wiki/Caliphate" title="Caliphate">Caliphate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emirate" title="Emirate">Emirate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Imamate" title="Imamate">Imamate</a> and <a href="/wiki/Khanate" title="Khanate">Khanate</a> (<a href="/wiki/List_of_Latin_phrases_(E)" title="List of Latin phrases (E)">e.g.</a> the <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a>).
</p><p>In <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_economic_jurisprudence" title="Islamic economic jurisprudence">Islamic economic jurisprudence</a>, hoarding of wealth is reviled and thus <a href="/wiki/Monopoly" title="Monopoly">monopolistic</a> behavior is frowned upon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[380]</a></sup> Attempts to comply with shariah has led to the development of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_banking" title="Islamic banking">Islamic banking</a>. Islam prohibits <i><a href="/wiki/Riba" title="Riba">riba</a></i>, usually translated as <a href="/wiki/Usury" title="Usury">usury</a>, which refers to any unfair gain in trade and is most commonly used to mean interest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[381]</a></sup> Instead, Islamic banks go into partnership with the borrower and both share from the profits and any losses from the venture. Another feature is the avoidance of uncertainty, which is seen as gambling<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[382]</a></sup> and Islamic banks traditionally avoid derivative instruments such as futures or options which substantially protected them from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2008_financial_crisis" title="2008 financial crisis">2008 financial crisis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[383]</a></sup> The state used to be involved in distribution of charity from the treasury, known as <a href="/wiki/Bayt_al-mal" title="Bayt al-mal">Bayt al-mal</a>, before it became a largely individual pursuit. The first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caliph" title="Caliph">Caliph</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abu_Bakr" title="Abu Bakr">Abu Bakr</a>, distributed zakat as one of the first examples of a <a href="/wiki/Guaranteed_minimum_income" title="Guaranteed minimum income">guaranteed minimum income</a>, with each man, woman and child getting 10 to 20 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dirhams" title="Dirhams">dirhams</a> annually.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[384]</a></sup> During the reign of the second Caliph Umar, <a href="/wiki/Child_support" title="Child support">child support</a> was introduced and the old and disabled were entitled to stipends,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[385]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[386]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[387]</a></sup> while the Umayyad Caliph <a href="/wiki/Umar_II" title="Umar II">Umar II</a> assigned a servant for each blind person and for every two chronically ill persons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[388]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jihad means "to strive or struggle [in the way of God]" and, in its broadest sense, is "exerting one's utmost power, efforts, endeavors, or ability in contending with an object of <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/disapprobation" title="wikt:disapprobation">disapprobation</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFirestone199917â18_399-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFirestone199917â18-399">[389]</a></sup> This could refer to one's striving to attain religious and moral perfection<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:17_400-0"><a href="#cite_note-:17-400">[390]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[391]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[392]</a></sup> with the Shia and Sufis in particular, distinguishing between the "greater jihad", which pertains to spiritual <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Self-improvement" title="Self-improvement">self-perfection</a>, and the "lesser jihad", defined as warfare.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFirestone199917_403-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFirestone199917-403">[393]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EI2_404-0"><a href="#cite_note-EI2-404">[394]</a></sup> When used without a qualifier, jihad is often understood in its military form.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFirestone199917â18_399-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFirestone199917â18-399">[389]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:17_400-1"><a href="#cite_note-:17-400">[390]</a></sup> Jihad is the only form of warfare permissible in Islamic law and may be declared against illegal works, terrorists, criminal groups, rebels, <a href="/wiki/Apostasy_in_Islam" title="Apostasy in Islam">apostates</a>, and leaders or states who oppress Muslims.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFirestone199917_403-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFirestone199917-403">[393]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EI2_404-1"><a href="#cite_note-EI2-404">[394]</a></sup> Most Muslims today interpret Jihad as only a defensive form of warfare.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[395]</a></sup> Jihad only becomes an individual duty for those vested with authority. For the rest of the populace, this happens only in the case of a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/General_mobilization" title="General mobilization">general mobilization</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EI2_404-2"><a href="#cite_note-EI2-404">[394]</a></sup> For most <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Twelver" title="Twelver">Twelver Shias</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Offensive_jihad" title="Offensive jihad">offensive jihad</a> can only be declared by a <a href="/wiki/Imamate_in_Twelver_doctrine" title="Imamate in Twelver doctrine">divinely appointed leader</a> of the Muslim community, and as such, is suspended since <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_al-Mahdi" title="Muhammad al-Mahdi">Muhammad al-Mahdi</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Occultation_(Islam)" title="Occultation (Islam)">occultation</a> is 868Â CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESachedina1998105â106_406-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESachedina1998105â106-406">[396]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENasr200372_407-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENasr200372-407">[397]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Daily_and_family_life">Daily and family life</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Adab_(Islam)" title="Adab (Islam)">Adab (Islam)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islamic_dietary_laws" title="Islamic dietary laws">Islamic dietary laws</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islam_and_children" title="Islam and children">Islam and children</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marriage_in_Islam" title="Marriage in Islam">Marriage in Islam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Women_in_Islam" title="Women in Islam">Women in Islam</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Polygyny_in_Islam" title="Polygyny in Islam">Polygyny in Islam</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Salat_Eid_al-Fitr,_Tehran_(113344343).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="392" data-file-width="479" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Salat_Eid_al-Fitr%2C_Tehran_%28113344343%29.jpg/220px-Salat_Eid_al-Fitr%2C_Tehran_%28113344343%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Salat_Eid_al-Fitr%2C_Tehran_%28113344343%29.jpg/330px-Salat_Eid_al-Fitr%2C_Tehran_%28113344343%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Salat_Eid_al-Fitr%2C_Tehran_%28113344343%29.jpg/440px-Salat_Eid_al-Fitr%2C_Tehran_%28113344343%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Salat_Eid_al-Fitr,_Tehran_(113344343).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Islamic <a href="/wiki/Hijab" title="Hijab">veils</a> represent <a href="/wiki/Morality_in_Islam#Modesty_and_humility" title="Morality in Islam">modesty</a></div></div></div>
<p>Many daily practices fall in the category of <i>adab</i>, or etiquette and this includes greeting others with "<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/As-Salamu_Alaykum" title="As-Salamu Alaykum">as-salamu 'alaykum</a></i>" ("peace be unto you"), saying <i><a href="/wiki/Basmala" title="Basmala">bismillah</a></i> ("in <a href="/wiki/Names_of_God" title="Names of God">the name of God</a>") before meals, and using only the right hand for eating and drinking.
</p><p>Specific prohibited foods include pork products, blood and <a href="/wiki/Carrion" title="Carrion">carrion</a>. Health is viewed as a trust from God and <a href="/wiki/Khamr" title="Khamr">intoxicants</a>, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alcoholic_drink" title="Alcoholic drink">alcoholic drinks</a>, are prohibited.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bahammam_408-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bahammam-408">[398]</a></sup> All meat must come from a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Herbivorous" title="Herbivorous">herbivorous</a> animal slaughtered in the name of God by a Muslim, Jew, or Christian, except for game that one has hunted or fished for themself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[399]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[400]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[401]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[402]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[403]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[404]</a></sup> Beards are often encouraged among men as something natural<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[405]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[406]</a></sup> and body modifications, such as <a href="/wiki/Religious_perspectives_on_tattooing#Islam" title="Religious perspectives on tattooing">permanent tattoos</a>, are usually forbidden as violating the creation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[f]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[408]</a></sup> Gold and silk for men are prohibited and are seen as extravagant.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[409]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Haya_(Islam)" title="Haya (Islam)">Haya</a></i>, often translated as "shame" or "modesty", is sometimes described as the innate character of Islam<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[410]</a></sup> and informs much of Muslim daily life. For example, <a href="/wiki/Islamic_clothing" title="Islamic clothing">clothing in Islam</a> emphasizes a standard of modesty, which has included the <a href="/wiki/Hijab" title="Hijab">hijab</a> for women. Similarly, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_hygienical_jurisprudence" title="Islamic hygienical jurisprudence">personal hygiene</a> is encouraged with certain requirements.
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Marriage_in_Islam" title="Marriage in Islam">Islamic marriage</a>, the groom is required to pay a bridal gift (<i><a href="/wiki/Mahr" title="Mahr">mahr</a></i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[411]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[412]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[413]</a></sup>
Most families in the Islamic world are monogamous.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[414]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[415]</a></sup> However, Muslim men are allowed to practice <a href="/wiki/Polygyny" title="Polygyny">polygyny</a> and can have up to four wives at the same time. There are also cultural variations in weddings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[416]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Polyandry" title="Polyandry">Polyandry</a>, a practice wherein a woman takes on two or more husbands, is prohibited in Islam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[417]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the birth of a child, the <a href="/wiki/Adhan" title="Adhan">Adhan</a> is pronounced in the right ear.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampo2009106_429-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampo2009106-429">[418]</a></sup> On the seventh day, the <i><a href="/wiki/Aqiqah" title="Aqiqah">aqiqah</a></i> ceremony is performed, in which an animal is sacrificed and its meat is distributed among the poor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENigosian2004[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidmy7hnALd_NkCpgPA120_120]_430-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENigosian2004[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidmy7hnALd_NkCpgPA120_120]-430">[419]</a></sup> The child's head is shaved, and an amount of money equaling the weight of its hair is donated to the poor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENigosian2004[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidmy7hnALd_NkCpgPA120_120]_430-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENigosian2004[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidmy7hnALd_NkCpgPA120_120]-430">[419]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Khitan_(circumcision)" title="Khitan (circumcision)">Male circumcision</a> is practised. Respecting and obeying one's parents, and taking care of them especially in their old age is a religious obligation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampo2009136_431-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampo2009136-431">[420]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[421]</a></sup>
</p><p>A <a href="/wiki/Islamic_view_of_death" title="Islamic view of death">dying Muslim</a> is encouraged to pronounce the <i><a href="/wiki/Shahada" title="Shahada">Shahada</a></i> as their last words. Paying respects to the dead and attending funerals in the community are considered among the virtuous acts. In <a href="/wiki/Islamic_funeral" title="Islamic funeral">Islamic burial rituals</a>, burial is encouraged as soon as possible, usually within 24 hours. The body is washed, except for martyrs, by members of the same gender and enshrouded in a garment that must not be elaborate called <i>kafan</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStefon2010[httpsarchiveorgdetailsislamicbeliefspr0000stefpage83_83]_433-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStefon2010[httpsarchiveorgdetailsislamicbeliefspr0000stefpage83_83]-433">[422]</a></sup> A "funeral prayer" called <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salat_al-Janazah" title="Salat al-Janazah">Salat al-Janazah</a></i> is performed. Wailing, or loud, mournful outcrying, is discouraged. Coffins are often not preferred and graves are often unmarked, even for kings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[423]</a></sup> Regarding inheritance, a son's share is double that of a daughter's.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[vi]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Arts_and_culture">Arts and culture</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Islamic_culture" title="Islamic culture">Islamic culture</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Islamic_art" title="Islamic art">Islamic art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islamic_architecture" title="Islamic architecture">Islamic architecture</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Islamic_literature" title="Islamic literature">Islamic literature</a></div>
<p>The term "<a href="/wiki/Islamic_culture" title="Islamic culture">Islamic culture</a>" can be used to mean aspects of culture that pertain to the religion, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Festivals" title="Festivals">festivals</a> and dress code. It is also controversially used to denote the cultural aspects of traditionally Muslim people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[424]</a></sup> Finally, "Islamic civilization" may also refer to the aspects of the synthesized culture of the early Caliphates, including that of non-Muslims,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEsposito201056_437-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEsposito201056-437">[425]</a></sup> sometimes referred to as "<a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Islamicate" title="wikt:Islamicate">Islamicate</a>".
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Islamic_art" title="Islamic art">Islamic art</a> encompasses the <a href="/wiki/Visual_arts" title="Visual arts">visual arts</a> including fields as varied as architecture, <a href="/wiki/Calligraphy" title="Calligraphy">calligraphy</a>, painting, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ceramics_(art)" title="Ceramics (art)">ceramics</a>, among others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438"><a href="#cite_note-438">[426]</a></sup> While the making of images of animate beings has often been frowned upon in connection with <a href="/wiki/Aniconism_in_Islam" title="Aniconism in Islam">laws against idolatry</a>, this rule has been interpreted in different ways by different scholars and in different historical periods. This stricture has been used to explain the prevalence of <a href="/wiki/Islamic_calligraphy" title="Islamic calligraphy">calligraphy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tessellation" title="Tessellation">tessellation</a>, and pattern as key aspects of Islamic artistic culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[427]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Islamic_architecture" title="Islamic architecture">Islamic architecture</a>, varying cultures show influence such as North African and Spanish Islamic architecture such as the <a href="/wiki/Great_Mosque_of_Kairouan" title="Great Mosque of Kairouan">Great Mosque of Kairouan</a> containing <a href="/wiki/Marble" title="Marble">marble</a> and <a href="/wiki/Porphyry_(geology)" title="Porphyry (geology)">porphyry</a> columns from Roman and Byzantine buildings,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[428]</a></sup> while <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mosques_in_Indonesia" title="Mosques in Indonesia">mosques in Indonesia</a> often have multi-tiered roofs from local <a href="/wiki/Java" title="Java">Javanese</a> styles.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Islamic calendar</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Lunar_calendar" title="Lunar calendar">lunar calendar</a> that begins with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hegira" title="Hegira">Hijra</a> of 622Â CE, a date that was reportedly chosen by Caliph Umar as it was an important turning point in Muhammad's fortunes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[429]</a></sup> Islamic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslim_holidays" title="Muslim holidays">holy days</a> fall on fixed dates of the lunar calendar, meaning they occur in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seasons" title="Seasons">different seasons</a> in different years in the <a href="/wiki/Gregorian_calendar" title="Gregorian calendar">Gregorian calendar</a>. The most important Islamic festivals are <i><a href="/wiki/Eid_al-Fitr" title="Eid al-Fitr">Eid al-Fitr</a></i> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø¹ÙØ¯ Ø§ÙÙ</span>) on the 1st of <i><a href="/wiki/Shawwal" title="Shawwal">Shawwal</a></i>, marking the end of the fasting month <i>Ramadan</i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Eid_al-Adha" title="Eid al-Adha">Eid al-Adha</a></i> (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø¹ÙØ¯ Ø§ÙØ£Ø¶Ø­Ù</span></span>) on the 10th of <i>Dhu al-Hijjah</i>, coinciding with the end of the <a href="/wiki/Hajj" title="Hajj">Hajj</a> (pilgrimage).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[430]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Derived_religions">Derived religions</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islam_and_Druze" title="Islam and Druze">Islam and Druze</a></div>
<p>Some movements, such as the <a href="/wiki/Druze" title="Druze">Druze</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[431]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[432]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[433]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[434]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[435]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Berghouata" title="Berghouata">Berghouata</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ha-Mim" title="Ha-Mim">Ha-Mim</a>, either emerged from Islam or came to share certain beliefs with Islam, and whether each is a separate religion or a sect of Islam is sometimes controversial. <a href="/wiki/Yazd%C3%A2nism" title="YazdÃ¢nism">YazdÃ¢nism</a> is seen as a blend of local Kurdish beliefs and Islamic Sufi doctrine introduced to <a href="/wiki/Kurdistan" title="Kurdistan">Kurdistan</a> by <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Adi_ibn_Musafir" title="Sheikh Adi ibn Musafir">Sheikh Adi ibn Musafir</a> in the 12thÂ century. <a href="/wiki/B%C3%A1bism" title="BÃ¡bism">BÃ¡bism</a> stems from Twelver Shia passed through <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Siyyid_%27Ali_Muhammad_i-Shirazi_al-Bab" title="Siyyid 'Ali Muhammad i-Shirazi al-Bab">Siyyid 'Ali Muhammad i-Shirazi al-Bab</a> while one of his followers Mirza Husayn 'Ali Nuri <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baha%27u%27llah" title="Baha'u'llah">Baha'u'llah</a> founded the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith" title="BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­ Faith">BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­ Faith</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[436]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">Sikhism</a>, founded by <a href="/wiki/Guru_Nanak" title="Guru Nanak">Guru Nanak</a> in late-fifteenth-century <a href="/wiki/Punjab" title="Punjab">Punjab</a>, primarily incorporates aspects of Hinduism, with some Islamic influences.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[437]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Criticism">Criticism</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_Islam" title="Criticism of Islam">Criticism of Islam</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:John_Damascus_(arabic_icon).gif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="574" data-file-width="364" decoding="async" height="284" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/John_Damascus_%28arabic_icon%29.gif/180px-John_Damascus_%28arabic_icon%29.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/John_Damascus_%28arabic_icon%29.gif/270px-John_Damascus_%28arabic_icon%29.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/John_Damascus_%28arabic_icon%29.gif/360px-John_Damascus_%28arabic_icon%29.gif 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:John_Damascus_(arabic_icon).gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/John_of_Damascus" title="John of Damascus">John of Damascus</a>, under the <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad Caliphate</a>, viewed Islamic doctrines as a hodgepodge from the <a href="/wiki/Bible" title="Bible">Bible</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[438]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Criticism of Islam has existed since Islam's formative stages. Early criticism came from Christian authors, many of whom viewed Islam as a Christian <a href="/wiki/Heresy" title="Heresy">heresy</a> or a form of <a href="/wiki/Idolatry" title="Idolatry">idolatry</a>, often explaining it in apocalyptic terms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFahlbusch_et_al2001[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidyaecVMhMWaECpgPA759_759]_451-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFahlbusch_et_al2001[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidyaecVMhMWaECpgPA759_759]-451">[439]</a></sup> Later, criticism from the Muslim world itself appeared, as well as from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish" title="Jewish">Jewish</a> writers and from <a href="/wiki/Ecclesiology" title="Ecclesiology">ecclesiastical Christians</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[440]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[441]</a></sup>
</p><p>Christian writers criticized Islamic salvation optimism and its carnality. Islam's sensual descriptions of paradise led many Christians to conclude that Islam was not a spiritual religion. Although sensual pleasure was also present in early Christianity, as seen in the writings of <a href="/wiki/Irenaeus" title="Irenaeus">Irenaeus</a>, the doctrines of the former <a href="/wiki/Manichaeism" title="Manichaeism">Manichaean</a>, <a href="/wiki/Augustine_of_Hippo" title="Augustine of Hippo">Augustine of Hippo</a>, led to the broad repudiation of bodily pleasure in both life and the afterlife. <a href="/wiki/Ali_ibn_Sahl_Rabban_al-Tabari" title="Ali ibn Sahl Rabban al-Tabari">Ali ibn Sahl Rabban al-Tabari</a> defended the Quranic description of paradise by asserting that the Bible also implies such ideas, such as drinking wine in the <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Matthew" title="Gospel of Matthew">Gospel of Matthew</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454"><a href="#cite_note-454">[442]</a></sup>
</p><p>Defamatory images of <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Christian_views_on_Muhammad" title="Medieval Christian views on Muhammad">Muhammad</a>, derived from early 7thÂ century depictions of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church_in_the_Byzantine_Empire" title="Eastern Orthodox Church in the Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Church</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceH_455-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceH-455">[443]</a></sup> appear in the 14th-century epic poem <i><a href="/wiki/Divine_Comedy" title="Divine Comedy">Divine Comedy</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Dante_Alighieri" title="Dante Alighieri">Dante Alighieri</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_456-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto-456">[444]</a></sup> Here, Muhammad appears in the eighth circle of hell, along with Ali. Dante does not blame Islam as a whole but accuses Muhammad of <a href="/wiki/Schism" title="Schism">schism</a>, by establishing another religion after Christianity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_456-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto-456">[444]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other criticisms focus on the question of human rights in modern Muslim-majority countries, and the treatment of women in Islamic law and practice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457"><a href="#cite_note-457">[445]</a></sup> In the wake of the recent <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism" title="Multiculturalism">multiculturalism</a> trend, Islam's influence on the ability of Muslim immigrants in the West to assimilate has been <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_multiculturalism" title="Criticism of multiculturalism">criticized</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[446]</a></sup> Both in his public and personal life, others objected to the morality of Muhammad, therefore also the sunnah as a role model.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459"><a href="#cite_note-459">[447]</a></sup>
</p>

<li id="cite_note-287"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-287">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLauziere2016">Lauziere, Henri (2016). <i>The Making of Salafism: ISLAMIC REFORM IN THE TWENTIETH CENTURY</i>. New York, Chichester, West Sussex: Columbia University Press. p.Â 237. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>Â <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-231-17550-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-231-17550-0"><bdi>978-0-231-17550-0</bdi></a>. <q>Prior to the fall of the Ottoman Empire, leading reformers who happened to be Salafi in creed were surprisingly open-minded: although they adhered to neo-Hanbali theology. However, the aftermath of the First World War and the expansion of European colonialism paved the way for a series of shifts in thought and attitude. The experiences of Rida offer many examples... he turned against the Shi'is who dared, with reason, to express doubts about the Saudi-Wahhabi project... . Shi'is were not the only victims: Rida and his associates showed their readiness to turn against fellow Salafis who questioned some of the Wahhabisâ religious interpretations.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Making+of+Salafism%3A+ISLAMIC+REFORM+IN+THE+TWENTIETH+CENTURY&amp;rft.place=New+York%2C+Chichester%2C+West+Sussex&amp;rft.pages=237&amp;rft.pub=Columbia+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-231-17550-0&amp;rft.aulast=Lauziere&amp;rft.aufirst=Henri&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIslam"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-288"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-288">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFG._Rabil2014">G. Rabil, Robert (2014). <i>Salafism in Lebanon: From Apoliticism to Transnational Jihadism</i>. Washington DC, USA: Georgetown University Press. pp.Â 32â33. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>Â <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-62616-116-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-62616-116-0"><bdi>978-1-62616-116-0</bdi></a>. <q>Western colonialists established in these countries political orders... that, even though not professing enmity to Islam and its institutions, left no role for Islam in society. This caused a crisis among Muslim reformists, who felt betrayed not only by the West but also by those nationalists, many of whom were brought to power by the West...  Nothing reflects this crisis more than the ideological transformation of Rashid Rida (1865â1935)... He also revived the works of Ibn Taymiyah by publishing his writings and promoting his ideas. Subsequently, taking note of the cataclysmic events brought about by Western policies in the Muslim world and shocked by the abolition of the caliphate, he transformed into a Muslim intellectual mostly concerned about protecting Muslim culture, identity, and politics from Western influence. He supported a theory that essentially emphasized the necessity of an Islamic state in which the scholars of Islam would have a leading role... Rida was a forerunner of Islamist thought. He apparently intended to provide a theoretical platform for a modern Islamic state. His ideas were later incorporated into the works of Islamic scholars. Significantly, his ideas influenced none other than Hassan al-Bannah, founder of the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt... The Muslim Brethren have taken up Rida's Islamic fundamentalism, a right-wing radical movement founded in 1928,..</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Salafism+in+Lebanon%3A+From+Apoliticism+to+Transnational+Jihadism&amp;rft.place=Washington+DC%2C+USA&amp;rft.pages=32-33&amp;rft.pub=Georgetown+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-62616-116-0&amp;rft.aulast=G.+Rabil&amp;rft.aufirst=Robert&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIslam"></span></span>
